(B) Since we are not told that the investigator suspects that the average weight is over 300 mg or is under 300 mg, and since a tablet containing too little or too much of a drug clearly should be brought to the manufacturer's attention, this is a two-sided test. Thus, the P-value is twice the tail probability obtained (using the t-distribution with df = n - 1 = 6).

content: A teacher believes that giving her students a practice quiz every week will motivate them to study harder, leading to a greater overall understanding of the course material. She tries this technique for a year, and everyone in the class achieves a grade of at least C. Is this an experiment or an observational study?

answers.A: <label>A. An experiment, but with no reasonable conclusion possible about cause and effect</label>
answers.B: <label>B. An experiment, thus making cause and effect a reasonable conclusion</label>
answers.C: <label>C. An observational study, because there was no use of a control group</label>
answers.D: <label>D. An observational study, but a poorly designed one because randomization was not used</label>
answers.E: <label>E. An observational study, and thus a reasonable conclusion of association but not of cause and effect</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) This study was an experiment because a treatment (weekly quizzes) was imposed on the subjects. However, it was a poorly designed experiment with no use of randomization and no control over confounding variables.

content: Which of the following is not true with regard to contingency tables for chi-square tests for independence?

answers.A: <label>A. The categories are not numerical for either variable.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Observed frequencies should be whole numbers.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Expected frequencies should be whole numbers.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Expected frequencies in each cell should be at least 5, and to achieve this, one sometimes combines categories for one or the other or both of the variables.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The expected frequency for any cell can be found by multiplying the row total by the column total and dividing by the sample size.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) The expected frequencies, as calculated by the rule in (E), may not be whole numbers.

content: Which of the following is a correct statement?

answers.A: <label>A. The probability of a Type II error does not depend on the probability of a Type I error.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. In conducting a hypothesis test, it is possible to simultaneously make both a Type I and a Type II error.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. A Type II error will result if one incorrectly assumes the data are normally distributed.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. When you choose a significance level α, you're setting the probability of a Type I error to exactly α.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) The probabilities of Type I and Type II error are related; for example, lowering the Type I error increases the probability of a Type II error. A Type I error can be made only if the null hypothesis is true, while a Type II error can be made only if the null hypothesis is false. In medical testing, with the usual null hypothesis that the patient is healthy, a Type I error is that a healthy patient is diagnosed with a disease, that is, a false positive. We reject H0 when the P-value falls below α, and when H0 is true this rejection will happen precisely with probability α.

content: Above is a scatterplot with one point labeled X. Suppose you find the least squares regression line. Which of the following is a correct statement?

answers.C: <label>C. The residual plot will show a curved pattern.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) X is probably very close to the least squares regression line and so has a small residual. Removing X will change the regression line very little if at all, and so it is not an influential point. The association between the x and y variables is very strong, just not linear. Correlation measures the strength of a linear relationship, which is very weak regardless of whether the point X is present or not.

content: A banking corporation advertises that 90% of the loan applications it receives are approved within 24 hours. In a random sample of 50 applications, what is the expected number of loan applications that will be turned down?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) The probability of an application being turned down is 1 - 0.90 = 0.10, and the expected value of a binomial with n = 50 and p = 0.10 is np = 50(0.10).

content:
The parallel boxplots below show monthly rainfall summaries for Liberia, West Africa.

Which of the following months has the least variability as measured by interquartile range?
explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) A boxplot gives a five-number summary: smallest value, 25th percentile (Q1), median, 75th percentile (Q3), and largest value. The interquartile range is given by Q3 - Q1, or the total length of the two "boxes" minus the "whiskers."

content: In comparing the life expectancies of two models of refrigerators, the average years before complete breakdown of 10 model A refrigerators is compared with that of 15 model B refrigerators. The 90% confidence interval estimate of the difference is (6, 12). Which of the following is the most reasonable conclusion?

answers.A: <label>A. The mean life expectancy of one model is twice that of the other.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The mean life expectancy of one model is 6 years, while the mean life expectancy of the other is 12 years.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The probability that the life expectancies are different is 0.90.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The probability that the difference in life expectancies is greater than 6 years is 0.90.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. We should be 90% confident that the difference in life expectancies is between 6 and 12 years.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) Using a measurement from a sample, we are never able to say exactly what a population mean is; rather we always say we have a certain confidence that the population mean lies in a particular interval.

content: A company wishes to determine the relationship between the number of days spent training employees and their performances on a job aptitude test. Collected data result in a least squares regression line, = 12.1 + 6.2x, where x is the number of training days and is the predicted score on the aptitude test. Which of the following statements best interprets the slope and y-intercept of the regression line?

answers.A: <label>A. The base score on the test is 12.1, and for every day of training one would expect, on average, an increase of 6.2 on the aptitude test.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The base score on the test is 6.2, and for every day of training one would expect, on average, an increase of 12.1 on the aptitude test.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The mean number of training days is 12.1, and for every additional 6.2 days of training one would expect, on average, an increase of one unit on the aptitude test.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The mean number of training days is 6.2, and for every additional 12.1 days of training one would expect, on average, an increase of one unit on the aptitude test.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The mean number of training days is 12.1, and for every day of training one would expect, on average, an increase of 6.2 on the aptitude test.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) The slope, 6.2, gives the predicted average increase in the y-variable for each unit increase in the x-variable.

content: To survey the opinions of the students at your high school, a researcher plans to select every twenty-fifth student entering the school in the morning. Assuming there are no absences, will this result in a simple random sample of students attending your school?

answers.A: <label>A. Yes, because every student has the same chance of being selected.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Yes, but only if there is a single entrance to the school.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Yes, because the 24 out of every 25 students who are not selected will form a control group.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Yes, because this is an example of systematic sampling, which is a special case of simple random sampling.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. No, because not every sample of the intended size has an equal chance of being selected.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) For a simple random sample, every possible group of the given size has to be equally likely to be selected, and this is not true here. For example, with this procedure it will be impossible for all the early arrivals to be together in the final sample. This procedure is an example of systematic sampling, but systematic sampling does not result in simple random samples.

content: Consider a hypothesis test with H0 : μ = 70 and Ha : μ < 70. Which of the following choices of significance level and sample size results in the greatest power of the test when μ = 65?

answers.E: <label>E. There is no way of answering without knowing the strength of the given power.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Power = 1 - β, and β is smallest when α is more and n is more.

content: Suppose that 60% of a particular electronic part last over 3 years, while 70% last less than 6 years. Assuming a normal distribution, what are the mean and standard deviation with regard to length of life of these parts?

answers.E: <label>E. The mean and standard deviation cannot be computed from the information given.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) The critical z-scores for 60% to the right and 70% to the left are -0.253 and 0.524, respectively. Then {μ - 0.253σ = 3, μ + 0.524σ = 6} gives μ = 3.977 and σ = 3.861.

content: The label on a package of cords claims that the breaking strength of a cord is 3.5 pounds, but a hardware store owner believes the real value is less. She plans to test 36 such cords; if their mean breaking strength is less than 3.25 pounds, she will reject the claim on the label. If the standard deviation for the breaking strengths of all such cords is 0.9 pounds, what is the probability of mistakenly rejecting a true claim?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) We have H0: μ = 3.5 and Ha: μ < 3.5. Then and the z-score of 3.25 is .

content:
The graph below shows cumulative proportions plotted against numbers of employees working in mid-sized retail establishments.

What is the approximate interquartile range?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) The cumulative proportions of 0.25 and 0.75 correspond to Q1 = 57 and Q3 = 75, respectively, and so the interquartile range is 75 - 57 = 18.

content: What is a placebo?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) A placebo is a control treatment in which members of the control group do not realize whether or not they are receiving the experimental treatment.

content: To study the effect of alcohol on reaction time, subjects were randomly selected and given three beers to consume. Their reaction time to a simple stimulus was measured before and after drinking the alcohol. Which of the following is a correct statement?

answers.A: <label>A. This study was an observational study.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Lack of blocking makes this a poorly designed study.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The placebo effect is irrelevant in this type of study.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. This study was an experiment with no controls.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. This study was an experiment in which the subjects were used as their own controls.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) In experiments on people, subjects can be used as their own controls, with responses noted before and after the treatment. However, with such designs there is always the danger of a placebo effect. In this case, subjects might well have slower reaction times after drinking the alcohol because they think they should. Thus the design of choice would involve a separate control group to use for comparison. Blocking is not necessary for a well-designed experiment, and there is no indication that it would be useful here.

content: Suppose that the regression line for a set of data, = 7x + b, passes through the point (-2, 4). If and are the sample means of the x- and y-values, respectively, then =
explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) Since (-2, 4) is on the line = 7x + b, we have 4 = -14 + b and b = 18. Thus the regression line is = 7x + 18. The point (, ) is always on the regression line, and so we have = 7 + 18.

content: Which of the following is a false statement about simple random samples?

answers.A: <label>A. A sample must be reasonably large to be properly considered a simple random sample.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Inspection of a sample will give no indication of whether or not it is a simple random sample.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Attributes of a simple random sample may be very different from attributes of the population.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Every element of the population has an equal chance of being picked.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Every sample of the desired size has an equal chance of being picked.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) A simple random sample can be any size.

content: A local school has seven math teachers and seven English teachers. When comparing their mean salaries, which of the following is most appropriate?

answers.E: <label>E. None of the above are appropriate.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) With such small populations, censuses instead of samples are used, and there is no resulting probability statement about the difference.

content:
Following is a histogram of ages of people applying for a particular high school teaching position.

Which of the following is a correct statement?

answers.A: <label>A. The median age is between 24 and 25.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The mean age is between 22 and 23.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The mean age is greater than the median age.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. More applicants are under 23 years of age than are over 23.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. There are a total of 10 applicants.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Half the area is on either side of 23, so 23 is the median. The distribution is skewed to the right, and so the mean is greater than the median. With half the area to each side of 23, half the applicants' ages are to each side of 23. Histograms such as this show relative frequencies, not actual frequencies.

content: To conduct a survey of which long distance carriers are used in a particular locality, a researcher opens a telephone book to a random page, closes his eyes, puts his finger down on the page, and then calls the next 75 names. Which of the following is a correct statement?

answers.A: <label>A. The procedure results in a simple random sample.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. While the survey design does incorporate chance, the procedure could easily result in selection bias.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. This is an example of cluster sampling with 26 clusters.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. This is an example of stratified sampling with 26 strata.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Given that the researcher truly keeps his eyes closed, this is a good example of blinding.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) While the procedure does use some element of chance, all possible groups of size 75 do not have the same chance of being picked, so the result is not a simple random sample. There is a real chance of selection bias. For example, a number of relatives with the same name and all using the same long-distance carrier might be selected.

content: Which of the following is not true about t-distributions?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) While t-distributions do have mean 0, their standard deviations are greater than 1.

content: Suppose the probability that a person picked at random has lung cancer is 0.035 and the probability that the person both has lung cancer and is a heavy smoker is 0.014. Given that someone picked at random has lung cancer, what is the probability that the person is a heavy smoker?
explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E)

content: Taxicabs in a metropolitan area are driven an average of 75,000 miles per year with a standard deviation of 12,000 miles. What is the probability that a randomly selected cab has been driven less than 100,000 miles if it is known that it has been driven over 80,000 miles? Assume a normal distribution of miles per year among cabs.
explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) The critical z-scores are and , with corresponding right tail probabilities of 0.3372 and 0.0188. The probability of being less than 100,000 given that the mileage is over 80,000 is

content: A plant manager wishes to determine the difference in number of accidents per day between two departments. She wants to be 90% certain of the difference in daily averages to within 0.25 accidents per day. Assume standard deviations of 0.8 and 0.5 accidents per day in the two departments, respectively. Which of the following should be used to determine how many days' (n) records should be examined?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A)

content: Suppose the correlation between two variables is r = 0.19. What is the new correlation if 0.23 is added to all values of the x-variable, every value of the y-variable is doubled, and the two variables are interchanged?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) The correlation coefficient is not changed by adding the same number to every value of one of the variables, by multiplying every value of one of the variables by the same positive number, or by interchanging the x- and y-variables.

content:
Two commercial flights per day are made from a small county airport. The airport manager tabulates the number of on-time departures for a sample of 200 days.

What is the χ2 statistic for a goodness-of-fit test that the distribution is binomial with probability equal to 0.8 that a flight leaves on time?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) The binomial distribution with n = 2 and p = 0.8 is P(0) = (0.2)2 = 0.04, P(1) = 2(0.2)(0.8) = 0.32, and P(2) = (0.8)2 = 0.64, resulting in expected numbers of 0.04(200) = 8, 0.32(200) = 64, and 0.64(200) = 128. Thus,

content: A company has a choice of three investment schemes. Option I gives a sure $25,000 return on investment. Option II gives a 50% chance of returning $50,000 and a 50% chance of returning $10,000. Option III gives a 5% chance of returning $100,000 and a 95% chance of returning nothing. Which option should the company choose?

answers.A: <label>A. Option II if it wants to maximize expected return</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Option I if it needs at least $20,000 to pay off an overdue loan</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Option III if it needs at least $80,000 to pay off an overdue loan</label>
answers.D: <label>D. All of the above answers are correct.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Because of chance, it really doesn't matter which option it chooses.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Option II gives the highest expected return: (50,000)(0.5) + (10,000)(0.5) = 30,000, which is greater than 25,000 and is also greater than (100,000)(0.05) = 5000. Option I guarantees that the $20,000 loan will be paid off. Option III provides the only chance of paying off the $80,000 loan. The moral is that the highest expected value is not automatically the "best" answer.

content: Suppose P(X) = 0.35 and P(Y) = 0.40. If P(X|Y) = 0.28, what is P(Y|X)?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B)

Then

content: To test whether extensive exercise lowers the resting heart rate, a study is performed by randomly selecting half of a group of volunteers to exercise 1 hour each morning, while the rest are instructed to perform no exercise. Is this study an experiment or an observational study?

answers.A: <label>A. An experiment with a control group and blinding</label>
answers.C: <label>C. An observational study with comparison and randomization</label>
answers.D: <label>D. An observational study with little if any bias</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) This study is an experiment because a treatment (extensive exercise) is imposed. There is no blinding because subjects clearly know whether or not they are exercising. There is no blocking because subjects are not divided into blocks before random assignment to treatments. For example, blocking would have been used if subjects had been separated by gender or age before random assignment to exercise or not.

content: The waiting times for a new roller coaster ride are normally distributed with a mean of 35 minutes and a standard deviation of 10 minutes. If there are 150,000 riders the first summer, which of the following is the shortest time interval associated with 100,000 riders?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) From the shape of the normal curve, the answer is in the middle. The middle two-thirds is between z-scores of ±0.97, and 35 ± 0.97(10) gives (25.3, 44.7).

content:
A medical researcher, studying the effective durations of three over-the-counter pain relievers, obtains the following boxplots from three equal-sized groups of patients, one group using each of the pain relievers.

Which of the following is a correct statement with regard to comparing the effective durations in minutes of the three pain relievers?

answers.A: <label>A. All three have the same interquartile range.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. More patients had over 210 minutes of pain relief in the (I) group than in either of the other two groups.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. More patients had over 240 minutes of pain relief in the (I) group than in either of the other two groups.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. More patients had less than 120 minutes of pain relief in the (III) group than in either of the other two groups.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The durations of pain relief in the (II) group form a normal distribution.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) The interquartile range is the length of the box, so they are not all equal. More than 25% of the patients in the A group had over 210 minutes of pain relief, which is not the case for the other two groups. There is no way to positively conclude a normal distribution from a boxplot.

content: For their first exam, students in an AP Statistics class studied an average of 4 hours with a standard deviation of 1 hour. Almost everyone did poorly on the exam, and so for the second exam every student studied 10 hours. What is the correlation between the numbers of hours students studied for each exam?

answers.E: <label>E. There is not sufficient information to answer this question.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) A scatterplot would be horizontal; the correlation is zero.

content: Suppose that 54% of the graduates from your high school go on to 4-year colleges, 20% go on to 2-year colleges, 19% find employment, and the remaining 7% search for a job. If a randomly selected student is not going on to a 2-year college, what is the probability she will be going on to a 4-year college?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D)

content: We are interested in the proportion p of people who are unemployed in a large city. Eight percent of a simple random sample of 500 people are unemployed. What is the midpoint for a 95% confidence interval estimate of p?
explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) The midpoint of the confidence interval is 0.08.

content: Random samples of size n are drawn from a population. The mean of each sample is calculated, and the standard deviation of this set of sample means is found. Then the procedure is repeated, this time with samples of size 4n. How does the standard deviation of the second group compare with the standard deviation of the first group?

answers.B: <label>B. It will be twice as large.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. It will be four times as large.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. It will be half as large.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. It will be one-quarter as large.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Increasing the sample size by a multiple of d2 divides the standard deviation of the set of sample means by d.

content:
Leech therapy is used in traditional medicine for treating localized pain. In a double blind experiment on 50 patients with osteoarthritis of the knee, half are randomly selected to receive injections of leech saliva while the rest receive a placebo. Pain levels 7 days later among those receiving the saliva show a mean of 19.5, while pain levels among those receiving the placebo show a mean of 25.6 (higher numbers indicate more pain). Partial calculator output is shown below.

Which of the following is a correct conclusion?

answers.A: <label>A. After 7 days, the mean pain level with the leech treatment is significantly lower than the mean pain level with the placebo at the 0.01 significance level.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. After 7 days, the mean pain level with the leech treatment is significantly lower than the mean pain level with the placebo at the 0.05 significance level, but not at the 0.01 level.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. After 7 days, the mean pain level with the leech treatment is significantly lower than the mean pain level with the placebo at the 0.10 significance level, but not at the 0.05 level.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. After 7 days, the mean pain level with the leech treatment is not significantly lower than the mean pain level with the placebo at the 0.10 significance level.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) With df = 43.43 and t = -3.94, the P-value is 0.000146 < 0.01. [On the TI-84, use tcdf.]

content: A survey was conducted to determine the percentage of parents who would support raising the legal driving age to 18. The results were stated as 67% with a margin of error of ±3%. What is meant by ±3%?

answers.A: <label>A. Three percent of the population were not surveyed.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. In the sample, the percentage of parents who would support raising the driving age is between 64% and 70%.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The percentage of the entire population of parents who would support raising the driving age is between 64% and 70%.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. It is unlikely that the given sample proportion result could be obtained unless the true percentage was between 64% and 70%.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Between 64% and 70% of the population were surveyed.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) While the sample proportion is between 64% and 70% (more specifically, it is 67%), this is not the meaning of Â±3%. While the percentage of the entire population is likely to be between 64% and 70%, this is not known for certain.

content: It is estimated that 30% of all cars parked in a metered lot outside City Hall receive tickets for meter violations. In a random sample of 5 cars parked in this lot, what is the probability that at least one receives a parking ticket?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) In this binomial situation, the probability that a car does not receive a ticket is 1 - 3 = 0.7, the probability that none of the five cars receives a ticket is (0.7)5, and thus the probability that at least one receives a ticket is 1 - (0.7)5.

content: Data are collected on income levels x versus number of bank accounts y. Summary calculations give = 32,000; sx = 11,500; = 1.7; sy = 0.4, and r = 0.42. What is the slope of the least squares regression line of number of bank accounts on income level?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A)

content: Given that the sample has a standard deviation of zero, which of the following is a true statement?

answers.A: <label>A. The standard deviation of the population is also zero.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The sample mean and sample median are equal.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The population has a symmetric distribution.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. All samples from the same population will also have a standard deviation of zero.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) If the standard deviation of a set is zero, all the values in the set are equal. The mean and median would both equal this common value and so would equal each other. If all the values are equal, there are no outliers. Just because the sample happens to have one common value, there is no reason for this to be true for the whole population. Statistics from one sample can be different from statistics from any other sample.

content: In one study half of a class were instructed to watch exactly 1 hour of television per day, the other half were told to watch 5 hours per day, and then their class grades were compared. In a second study students in a class responded to a questionnaire asking about their television usage and their class grades.

answers.A: <label>A. The first study was an experiment without a control group, while the second was an observational study.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The first study was an observational study, while the second was a controlled experiment.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Each study was part controlled experiment and part observational study.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) The first study is an experiment with two treatment groups and no control group. The second study is observational; the researcher did not randomly divide the subjects into groups and have each group watch a designated number of hours of television per night.

content: All of the following statements are true for all discrete random variables except for which one?

answers.A: <label>A. The possible outcomes must all be numerical.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The possible outcomes must be mutually exclusive.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The mean (expected value) always equals the sum of the products obtained by multiplying each value by its corresponding probability.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The standard deviation of a random variable can never be negative.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Approximately 95% of the outcomes will be within two standard deviations of the mean.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) This refers only to very particular random variables, for example, random variables whose values are the numbers of successes in a binomial probability distribution with large n.

content: In leaving for school on an overcast April morning you make a judgment on the null hypothesis: The weather will remain dry. What would the results be of Type I and Type II errors?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) A Type I error means that the null hypothesis is correct (the weather will remain dry), but you reject it (thus you needlessly carry around an umbrella). A Type II error means that the null hypothesis is wrong (it will rain), but you fail to reject it (thus you get drenched).

content: The mean thrust of a certain model jet engine is 9500 pounds. Concerned that a production process change might have lowered the thrust, an inspector tests a sample of units, calculating a mean of 9350 pounds with a z-score of -2.46 and a P-value of 0.0069. Which of the following is the most reasonable conclusion?

answers.A: <label>A. 99.31% of the engines produced under the new process will have a thrust under 9350 pounds.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. 99.31% of the engines produced under the new process will have a thrust under 9500 pounds.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. 0.69% of the time an engine produced under the new process will have a thrust over 9500 pounds.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. There is evidence to conclude that the new process is producing engines with a mean thrust under 9350 pounds.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. There is evidence to conclude that the new process is producing engines with a mean thrust under 9500 pounds.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) If the sample statistic is far enough away from the claimed population parameter, we say that there is sufficient evidence to reject the null hypothesis. In this case the null hypothesis is that μ = 9500. The P-value is the probability of obtaining a sample statistic as extreme or more extreme than the one obtained if the null hypothesis is assumed to be true. The smaller the P-value, the more significant the difference between the null hypothesis and the sample results. With P = 0.0069, there is strong evidence to reject H0.

content: In a group of 10 third graders, the mean height is 50 inches with a median of 47 inches, while in a group of 12 fourth graders, the mean height is 54 inches with a median of 49 inches. What is the median height of the combined group?

answers.E: <label>E. The median of the combined group cannot be determined from the given information.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) There are 10 + 12 = 22 students in the combined group. In ascending order, where are the two middle scores? At least 5 third graders and 6 fourth graders have heights less than or equal to 49 inches, so at most 11 students have heights greater than or equal to 49 and thus the median is less than or equal to 49. At least 5 third graders and 6 fourth graders have heights greater than or equal to 47 inches, so at most 11 students have heights less than or equal to 47 and thus the median is greater than or equal to 47. All that can be said about the median of the combined group is that it is between 47 and 49 inches.

content: A reading specialist in a large public school system believes that the more time students spend reading, the better they will do in school. She plans a middle school experiment in which an SRS of 30 eighth graders will be assigned four extra hours of reading per week, an SRS of 30 seventh graders will be assigned two extra hours of reading per week, and an SRS of 30 sixth graders with no extra assigned reading will be a control group. After one school year, the mean GPAs from each group will be compared. Is this a good experimental design?

answers.B: <label>B. No, because while this design may point out an association between reading and GPA, it cannot establish a cause-and-effect relationship.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. No, because without blinding, there is a strong chance of a placebo effect.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. No, because any conclusion would be flawed because of blocking bias.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. No, because grade level is a lurking variable which may well be confounded with the variables under consideration.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) Good experimental design aims to give each group the same experiences except for the treatment under consideration, Thus, all three SRSs should be picked from the same grade level.

content:
A study at 35 large city high schools gives the following back-to-back stemplot of the percentages of students who say they have tried alcohol.

Which of the following does not follow from the above data?

answers.A: <label>A. In general, the percentage of students trying alcohol seems to have increased from 1995-96 to 1998-99.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The median alcohol percentage among the 35 schools increased from 1995-96 to 1998-99.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The spread between the lowest and highest alcohol percentages decreased from 1995-96 to 1998-99.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. For both school years in most of the 35 schools, most of the students said they had tried alcohol.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The percentage of students trying alcohol increased in each of the schools between 1995-96 and 1998-99.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) The stemplot does not indicate what happened for any individual school.

content: The mean and standard deviation of the population {1, 5, 8, 11, 15} are μ = 8 and σ = 4.8, respectively. Let S be the set of the 125 ordered triples (repeats allowed) of elements of the original population. Which of the following is a correct statement about the mean and standard deviation of the means of the triples in S?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B)

content:
Consider the following studies being run by three different AP Statistics instructors.

I.One rewards students every day with lollipops for relaxation, encouragement, and motivation to learn the material.

II.One promises that all students will receive A's as long as they give their best efforts to learn the material.

III.One is available every day after school and on weekends so that students with questions can come in and learn the material.

answers.A: <label>A. None of these studies use randomization.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. None of these studies use control groups.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. None of these studies use blinding.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Important information can be found from all these studies, but none can establish causal relationships.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) None of the studies have any controls such as randomization, a control group, or blinding, and so while they may give valuable information, they cannot establish cause and effect.

content:
A survey to measure job satisfaction of high school mathematics teachers was taken in 1993 and repeated 5 years later in 1998. Each year a random sample of 50 teachers rated their job satisfaction on a 1-to-100 scale with higher numbers indicating greater satisfaction. The results are given in the following back-to-back stemplot.

What is the trend from 1993 to 1998 with regard to the standard deviation and range of the two samples?

answers.A: <label>A. Both the standard deviation and range increased.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The standard deviation increased, while the range decreased.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The range increased, while the standard deviation decreased.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Both the standard deviation and range decreased.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Both the standard deviation and range remained unchanged.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) The range increased from 90 - 15 = 75 to 97 - 21 = 76, while the standard deviation decreased (note how the values are bunched together more closely in 1998).

content: The number of days it takes to build a new house has a variance of 386. A sample of 40 new homes shows an average building time of 83 days. With what confidence can we assert that the average building time for a new house is between 80 and 90 days?
explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) normalcdf(80, 90, 83, 3.106) = 0.8208.

content: A shipment of resistors have an average resistance of 200 ohms with a standard deviation of 5 ohms, and the resistances are normally distributed. Suppose a randomly chosen resistor has a resistance under 194 ohms. What is the probability that its resistance is greater than 188 ohms?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) The critical z-scores are with corresponding left tail probabilities of 0.0082 and 0.1151, respectively. The probability of being greater than 188 given that it is less than 194 is

content: Suppose 4% of the population have a certain disease. A laboratory blood test gives a positive reading for 95% of people who have the disease and for 5% of people who do not have the disease. If a person tests positive, what is the probability the person has the disease?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C)

content: For which of the following is it appropriate to use a census?

answers.A: <label>A. A 95% confidence interval of mean height of teachers in a small town.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. A 95% confidence interval of the proportion of students in a small town who are taking some AP class.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. A two-tailed hypothesis test where the null hypothesis was that the mean expenditure on entertainment by male students at a high school is the same as that of female students.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Given a census, the population parameter is known, and there is no need to use the techniques of inference.

content: On the same test, Mary and Pam scored at the 64th and 56th percentiles, respectively. Which of the following is a true statement?

answers.A: <label>A. Mary scored eight more points than Pam.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Mary's score is 8% higher than Pam's.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Eight percent of those who took the test scored between Pam and Mary.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Thirty-six people scored higher than both Mary and Pam.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Sixty-four percent of the students scored below Mary and 56% scored below Pam, and so 8% must have scored between them.

content: Which of the following is a true statement?

answers.A: <label>A. While observational studies gather information on an already existing condition, they still often involve intentionally forcing some treatment to note the response.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. In an experiment, researchers decide on the treatment but typically allow the subjects to self-select into the control group.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. If properly designed, either observational studies or controlled experiments can easily be used to establish cause and effect.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Wording to disguise hidden interests in observational studies is the same idea as blinding in experimental design.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Stratifying in sampling is the same idea as blocking for experiments.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) Intentionally forcing some treatment to note the response is associated with controlled experiments, not with observational studies. In experiments, the researchers decide how people are placed in different groups; self-selection is associated with observational studies. Results of observational studies may suggest cause-and-effect relationships; however, controlled studies are used to establish such relationships.

content:
The random variable describing the number of minutes high school students spend in front of a computer daily has a mean of 200 minutes. Samples of two different sizes result in sampling distributions with the two graphs below.

Which of the following is a true statement?

answers.A: <label>A. Based on these graphs, no comparison between the two sample sizes is possible.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. More generally, sample sizes have no effect on sampling distributions.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The sample size in A is the same as the sample size in B.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The sample size in A is less than the sample size in B.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The sample size in A is greater than the sample size in B.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: <

Explanation:

(E) With , the greater the sample size n, the smaller the standard deviation .

content: To determine the mean cost of groceries in a certain city, an identical grocery basket of food is purchased at each store in a random sample of ten stores. If the average cost is $47.52 with a standard deviation of $1.59, find a 98% confidence interval estimate for the cost of these groceries in the city.
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) , and invT(.01, 9) = -2.821.

content: A set consists of four numbers. The largest value is 200, and the range is 50. Which of the following statements is true?

answers.E: <label>E. The median is the mean of the second and third numbers if the set is arranged in ascending order.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) The set could be {150, 150, 150, 200} with mean 162.5 and median 150. It might also be {150, 200, 200, 200} with mean 187.5 and median 200. The median of a set of four elements is the mean of the two middle elements.

content: A telephone survey of 400 registered voters showed that 256 had not yet made up their minds 1 month before the election. How sure can we be that between 60% and 68% of the electorate were still undecided at that time?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) normalcdf(.6, .68, .64, .024) = 0.9044.

content:
Suppose we have a random variable X where the probability associated with the value k is

What is the mean of X?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) This is a binomial with n = 15 and p = 0.29, and so the mean is np = 15(0.29) = 4.35.

content: The financial aid office at a state university conducts a study to determine the total student costs per semester. All students are charged $4500 for tuition. The mean cost for books is $350 with a standard deviation of $65. The mean outlay for room and board is $2800 with a standard deviation of $380. The mean personal expenditure is $675 with a standard deviation of $125. Assuming independence among categories, what is the standard deviation of the total student costs?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) With independence, variances add, so

content: Suppose X and Y are random variables with E(X) = 312, var(X) = 6, E(X) = 307, and var(Y) = 8. What are the expected value and variance of the random variable X + Y?

answers.E: <label>E. There is insufficient information to answer this question.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) Without independence we cannot determine var(X + Y) from the information given.

content: In sample surveys, what is meant by bias?

answers.A: <label>A. A systematic error in a sampling method that leads to an unrepresentative sample.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Prejudice, as in ethnic and gender-related studies.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Tendency for some distributions to be skewed.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Tendency for some distributions to vary from normality.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Bias is the tendency to favor the selection of certain members of a population. It has nothing to do with the shape of distributions. The natural variability between samples is called sampling error.

content:
The following histogram gives the shoe sizes of people in an elementary school building one morning.

Which of the following is a true statement?

answers.A: <label>A. The distribution of shoe sizes is bimodal.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The mean shoe size is less than the median shoe size.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Only 10% of the people had size 5 shoes.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) There are not two distinct peaks, so the distribution is not bimodal. Relative frequency is given by relative area. The distribution is skewed to the left, and so the mean is less than the median.

content: When comparing the standard normal (z) distribution to the t-distribution with df = 30, which of (A)-(D), if any, are false?

answers.E: <label>E. All the above are true statements.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) While the standard deviation of the z-distribution is 1, the standard deviation of the t-distribution is greater than 1.

content: Given a probability of 0.65 that interest rates will jump this year, and a probability of 0.72 that if interest rates jump the stock market will decline, what is the probability that interest rates will jump and the stock market will decline?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B)

content: Sampling error is

answers.A: <label>A. the mean of a sample statistic.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. the standard deviation of a sample statistic.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. the standard error of a sample statistic.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. the difference between a population parameter and an estimate of that parameter.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) Different samples give different sample statistics, all of which are estimates for the same population parameter, and so error, called sampling error, is naturally present.

content: Suppose that the weights of trucks traveling on the interstate highway system are normally distributed. If 70% of the trucks weigh more than 12,000 pounds and 80% weigh more than 10,000 pounds, what are the mean and standard deviation for the weights of trucks traveling on the interstate system?

answers.E: <label>E. The mean and standard deviation cannot be computed from the information given.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) With four-digit accuracy as found on the TI-84, the critical z-scores for 70% to the right and 80% to the right are -0.5244 and -0.8416, respectively. Then {μ - 0.5244σ = 12,000, μ - 0.8416σ = 10,000} gives μ = 15,306 and σ = 6305.

content: In the correlation coefficient r = 0.78, what percentage of variation in y is explained by the linear regression model?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) The percentage of the variation in y explained by the variation in x is given by the coefficient of determination r2. In this example, (0.78)2 = 0.61.

content:
Consider the following scatterplot:

Which of the following is the best estimate of the correlation between x and y?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) There is a weak negative correlation, and so -0.15 is the only reasonable possibility among the choices given.

content:
For one NBA playoff game the actual percentage of the television viewing public who watched the game was 24%. If you had taken a survey of 50 television viewers that night and constructed a confidence interval estimate of the percentage watching the game, which of the following would have been true?

I.The center of the interval would have been 24%.

II.The interval would have contained 24%.

III.A 99% confidence interval estimate would have contained 24%.
explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) There is no guarantee that 24 is anywhere near the interval, and so none of the statements is true.

content: Which of the following is a true statement?

answers.A: <label>A. In a well-designed, well-conducted sample survey, sampling error is effectively eliminated.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. In a well-designed observational study, responses are influenced through an orderly, carefully planned procedure during the collection of data.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. In a well-designed experiment, the treatments are carefully planned to result in responses that are as similar as possible.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. In a well-designed experiment, double-blinding is a useful matched pairs design.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. None of the above is a true statement.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) Sampling error relates to natural variation between samples, and it can never be eliminated. In good observational studies, responses are not influenced during the collection of data. In good experiments, treatments are compared as to the differences in responses.

content:
Consider the following scatterplot showing the relationship between caffeine intake and job performance.

Which of the following is a reasonable conclusion?

answers.A: <label>A. Low caffeine intake is associated with low job performance.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Low caffeine intake is associated with high job performance.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. High caffeine intake is associated with low job performance.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. High caffeine intake is associated with high job performance.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Job performance cannot be predicted from caffeine intake.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) The scatterplot suggests a zero correlation.

content: An author of a new book claims that anyone following his suggested diet program will lose an average of 2.8 pounds per week. A researcher believes that the true figure will be lower and plans a test involving a random sample of 36 overweight people. She will reject the author's claim if the mean weight loss in the volunteer group is less than 2.5 pounds per week. Assume that the standard deviation among individuals is 1.2 pounds per week. If the true mean value is 2.4 pounds per week, what is the probability that the researcher will mistakenly fail to reject the author's false claim of 2.8 pounds?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) , and to the right of 2.5 is the probability of failing to reject the false claim.

content: Which of the following is the central limit theorem?

answers.A: <label>A. No matter how the population is distributed, as the sample size increases, the mean of the sample means becomes closer to the mean of the population.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. No matter how the population is distributed, as the sample size increases, the standard deviation of the sample means becomes closer to the standard deviation of the population divided by the square root of the sample size.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. If the population is normally distributed, then as the sample size increases, the sampling distribution of the sample mean becomes closer to a normal distribution.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. All of the above together make up the central limit theorem.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The central limit theorem refers to something else.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) The central limit theorem says that no matter how the original population is distributed, as the sample size increases, the sampling distribution of the sample mean becomes closer to a normal distribution.

content: What is a sampling distribution?

answers.A: <label>A. A distribution of all the statistics that can be found in a given sample</label>
answers.B: <label>B. A histogram, or other such visual representation, showing the distribution of a sample</label>
answers.C: <label>C. A normal distribution of some statistic</label>
answers.D: <label>D. A distribution of all the values taken by a statistic from all possible samples of a given size</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) A sampling distribution is the distribution of all the values taken by a statistic, such as sample mean or sample proportion, from all possible samples of a given size.

content: A judge chosen at random reaches a just decision roughly 80% of the time. What is the probability that in randomly chosen cases at least two out of three judges reach a just decision?
explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) P(at least 2) = P(exactly 2) + P(exactly 3) = 3(0.8)2(0.2) + (0.8)3

content:
Miles per gallon versus speed (miles per hour) for a new model automobile is fitted with a least squares regression line. Following is computer output of the statistical analysis of the data.

Which of the following gives a 99% confidence interval for the slope of the regression line?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) The critical t-scores for 99% confidence with df = 6 are Â±3.707.

content:
What fault do all these sampling designs have in common?

I.The Parent-Teacher Association (PTA), concerned about rising teenage pregnancy rates at a high school, randomly picks a sample of high school students and interviews them concerning unprotected sex they have engaged in during the past year.

II.A radio talk show host asks people to phone in their views on whether the United States should keep troops in Bosnia indefinitely to enforce the cease-fire.

III.The Ladies Home Journal plans to predict the winner of a national election based on a survey of its readers.

answers.A: <label>A. All the designs make improper use of stratification.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. All the designs have errors that can lead to strong bias.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. All the designs confuse association with cause and effect.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. All the designs suffer from sampling error.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. None of the designs makes use of chance in selecting a sample.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) The PTA survey has strong response bias in that students may not give truthful responses to a parent or teacher about their engaging in unprotected sex. The talk show survey results in a voluntary response sample, which typically gives too much emphasis to persons with strong opinions. The Ladies Home Journal survey has strong selection bias; that is, people who read the Journal are not representative of the general population.

content: Hospital administrators wish to determine the average length of stay for all surgical patients. A statistician determines that for a 95% confidence level estimate of the average length of stay to within ±0.50 days, 100 surgical patients' records would have to be examined. How many records should be looked at for a 95% confidence level estimate to within ±0.25 days?

answers.E: <label>E. There is not enough information given to determine the necessary sample size.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) To divide the interval estimate by d, the sample size must be increased by a multiple of d2.

content: A chess master wins 80% of her games, loses 5%, and draws the rest. If she receives 1 point for a win, point for a draw, and no points for a loss, what is true about the sampling distribution X of the points scored in two independent games?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) P(0 pts) = (0.05)2, P( pt) = 2(0.05)(0.15), P(1 pt) = (0.15)2 + 2(0.05)(0.8), P(1 pts) = 2(0.15)(0.8), and P(2 pts) = (0.8)2.

content: Which of the following is a true statement?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) The P-value is the probability of obtaining a result as extreme or more extreme as the one seen given that the null hypothesis is true; thus, it is a conditional probability. The P-value depends on the sample chosen. The P-value in a two-sided test is calculated by doubling the indicated tail probability. P-values are not restricted to use with any particular distribution. With a small P-value, there is evidence to reject the null hypothesis, but we're not proving anything.

content: An assembly line machine is supposed to turn out ball bearings with a diameter of 1.25 centimeters. Each morning the first 30 bearings produced are pulled and measured. If their mean diameter is under 1.23 centimeters or over 1.27 centimeters, the machinery is stopped and an engineer is called to make adjustments before production is resumed. The quality control procedure may be viewed as a hypothesis test with the null hypothesis H0: μ = 1.25 and the alternative hypothesis Ha: μ ≠ 1.25. The engineer is asked to make adjustments when the null hypothesis is rejected. In test terminology, what would a Type II error result in?

answers.A: <label>A. A warranted halt in production to adjust the machinery</label>
answers.B: <label>B. An unnecessary stoppage of the production process</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Continued production of wrong size ball bearings</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Continued production of proper size ball bearings</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Continued production of ball bearings that randomly are the right or wrong size</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) A Type II error is a mistaken failure to reject a false null hypothesis or, in this case, a failure to realize that the machinery is turning out wrong size ball bearings.

content: Both over-the-counter niacin and the prescription drug Lipitor are known to lower blood cholesterol levels. In one double-blind study Lipitor outperformed niacin. The 95% confidence interval estimate of the difference in mean cholesterol level lowering was (18, 41). Which of the following is a reasonable conclusion?

answers.A: <label>A. Niacin lowers cholesterol an average of 18 points, while Lipitor lowers cholesterol an average of 41 points.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. There is a 0.95 probability that Lipitor will outperform niacin in lowering the cholesterol level of any given individual.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. There is a 0.95 probability that Lipitor will outperform niacin by at least 23 points in lowering the cholesterol level of any given individual.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. We should be 95% confident that Lipitor will outperform niacin as a cholesterol-lowering drug.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) Using a measurement from a sample, we are never able to say exactly what a population mean is; rather we always say we have a certain confidence that the population mean lies in a particular interval. In this case we are 95% confident that Lipitor will outperform niacin by 18 to 41 points.

content:
The following parallel boxplots show the average daily hours of bright sunshine in Liberia, West Africa:

For how many months is the median below 4 hours?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) The median number of hours is less than four for June, July, and August.

content:
Following is a cumulative probability graph for the number of births per day in a city hospital.

Assuming that a birthing room can be used by only one woman per day, how many rooms must the hospital have available to be able to meet the demand at least 90 percent of the days?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) A horizontal line drawn at the 0.9 probability level corresponds to roughly 19 rooms.

content:
The stemplot below shows ages of CEOs of a select group of corporations.

Which of the following is not a correct statement about this distribution?

answers.B: <label>B. The distribution is skewed left and right.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) There is no such thing as being skewed both left and right.

content: Which of the following is a true statement?

answers.A: <label>A. Stemplots are useful both for quantitative and categorical data sets.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Stemplots are equally useful for small and very large data sets.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Stemplots can show symmetry, gaps, clusters, and outliers.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Stemplots may or may not show individual values.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Stems may be skipped if there is no data value for a particular stem.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Stemplots are not used for categorical data sets, are too unwieldy to be used for very large data sets, and show every individual value. Stems should never be skipped overâ€”gaps are important to see.

content: Which of the following is an incorrect statement?

answers.A: <label>A. In histograms, relative areas correspond to relative frequencies.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. In histograms, frequencies can be determined from relative heights.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Symmetric histograms may have multiple peaks.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Two students working with the same set of data may come up with histograms that look different.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Displaying outliers may be more problematic when using histograms than when using stemplots.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Histograms give information about relative frequencies (relative areas correspond to relative frequencies) and may or may not have an axis with actual frequencies. Symmetric histograms can have any number of peaks. Choice of width and number of classes changes the appearance of a histogram. Stemplots clearly show outliers; however, in histograms outliers may be hidden in large class widths.

content:
Question below refers to the following five cumulative relative frequency plots:

To which of the above cumulative relative frequency plots does the following histogram correspond?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) A histogram with little area under the curve early and much greater area later results in a cumulative relative frequency plot that rises slowly at first and then at a much faster rate later.

content:
Question below refers to the following five cumulative relative frequency plots:

To which of the above cumulative relative frequency plots does the following histogram correspond?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) A histogram with large area under the curve early and much less area later results in a cumulative relative frequency plot that rises quickly at first and then at a much slower rate later.

content:
Question below refers to the following five cumulative relative frequency plots:

To which of the above cumulative relative frequency plots does the following histogram correspond?
explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) A histogram with little area under the curve in the middle and much greater area on both ends results in a cumulative relative frequency plot that rises quickly at first, then almost levels off, and finally rises quickly at the end.

content:
Question below refers to the following five cumulative relative frequency plots:

To which of the above cumulative relative frequency plots does the following histogram correspond?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) A histogram with little area under the curve on the ends and much greater area in the middle results in a cumulative relative frequency plot that rises slowly at first, then quickly in the middle, and finally slowly again at the end.

content:
Question below refers to the following five cumulative relative frequency plots:

To which of the above cumulative relative frequency plots does the following histogram correspond?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Uniform distributions result in cumulative relative frequency plots that rise at constant rates, thus linear.

content:
An auto manufacturer claims that the autos it sells have an average fuel efficiency of 35 mpg. A consumer group believes that the true figure is lower. The consumer group obtains 5 of the company's autos and determines an average of 32 mpg. Is this significant? The company runs a simulation by randomly picking 5 cars 160 times from a fleet of cars of known 35 mpg efficiency and calculating the resulting averages to show that 32 was possible. The company makes the following dotplot.

Does the company's argument seem reasonable given this dotplot?

answers.A: <label>A. Yes, because the dotplot shows that anything is possible in the real world.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Yes, because the dotplot shows that every average was not 35.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Yes, because the dotplot shows that 32 mpg is a possible average of 5 cars from a fleet of cars of known 35 mpg efficiency.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. No, because the dotplot shows that anything is possible in the real world.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. No, because the possibility of picking 5 cars with an average of 32 mpg or lower from a fleet of cars of known 35 mpg efficiency is very small, only 4 out of 160, or 0.025.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) The consumer group randomly picked 5 of the cars and found an average efficiency of only 32 mpg. The chance of picking 5 cars with an average of 32 mpg or lower from a fleet of cars of real 35 mpg efficiency is so small, only 4 out of 160, or 0.025, that it seems reasonable to conclude that the consumer group's set of 5 cars was not picked from a fleet of cars with 35 mpg efficiency and that the company's claim is wrong.

content:
The graph below shows household income in Laguna Woods, California.

What can be said about the ratio ?

answers.B: <label>B. Less than one, but definitely above zero</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Cannot be answered without knowing the standard deviation</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) The distribution is clearly skewed right, so the mean is greater than the median, and the ratio is greater than one.

content: Students in AP Statistics class were timed in seconds while solving a series of mathematical brainteasers. One student's time had a standardized score of z = 2.40. If the times are all changed to minutes, what will then be the student's standardized score?

answers.E: <label>E. The new standardized score cannot be determined without knowing the class mean.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Multiplying every value in a set by the same constant (in this case, by ) multiplies both the mean and the standard deviation by the same constant. Standardized scores (the number of standard deviations from the mean) are unchanged.

content:
Dieticians are concerned about sugar consumption in teenagers' diets (a 12-ounce can of soft drink typically has 10 teaspoons of sugar). In a random sample of 55 students, the number of teaspoons of sugar consumed for each student on a randomly selected day is tabulated. Summary statistics are noted below:

Which of the following is a true statement?

answers.A: <label>A. None of the values are outliers.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The value 10 is an outlier, and there can be no others.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The value 60 is an outlier, and there can be no others.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Both 10 and 60 are outliers, and there may be others.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The value 60 is an outlier, and there may be others at the high end of the data set.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) Outliers are any values below Q1 - 1.5(IQR) = 5.5 or above Q3 + 1.5(IQR) = 57.5.

content:
Problem below refers to the following five boxplots.

To which of the above boxplots does the following histogram correspond?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) The value 50 seems to split the area under the histogram in two, so the median is about 50. Furthermore, the histogram is skewed to the left with a tail from 0 to 30.

content:

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

(B) Looking at areas under the curve, Q1 appears to be around 20, the median is around 30, and Q3 is about 40.

To which of the above boxplots does the following histogram correspond?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

(C) Looking at areas under the curve, Q1 appears to be around 10, the median is around 30, and Q3 is about 50.

Correct Answer: C

(C) The boxplot indicates that 25% of the data lie in each of the intervals 10-20, 20-35, 35-40, and 40-50. Counting boxes, only histogram C has this distribution.

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

(D) The boxplot indicates that 25% of the data lie in each of the intervals 10-15, 15-25, 25-35, and 35-50. Counting boxes, only histogram D has this distribution.

content:
Problem below refers to the following five histograms:

To which of the above histograms does the following boxplot correspond?
explanation:
Correct Answer: E
