(E) The boxplot indicates that 25% of the data lie in each of the intervals 10-20, 20-30, 30-40, and 40-50. Counting boxes, only histogram E has this distribution.

content:
Below is a boxplot of CO2 levels (in grams per kilometer) for a sampling of 2008 vehicles.

Suppose follow-up testing determines that the low outlier should be 10 grams per kilometer less and the two high outliers should each be 5 grams per kilometer greater. What effect, if any, will these changes have on the mean and median CO2 levels?

answers.A: <label>A. Both the mean and median will be unchanged.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The median will be unchanged, but the mean will increase.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The median will be unchanged, but the mean will decrease.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The mean will be unchanged, but the median will increase.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Both the mean and median will change.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Subtracting 10 from one value and adding 5 to two values leaves the sum of the values unchanged, so the mean will be unchanged. Exactly what values the outliers take will not change what value is in the middle, so the median will be unchanged.

content:
Below is a boxplot of yearly tuition and fees of all four year colleges and universities in a Western state. The low outlier is from a private university that gives full scholarships to all accepted students, while the high outlier is from a private college catering to the very rich.

Removing both outliers will effect what changes, if any, on the mean and median costs for this state's four-year institutions of higher learning?

answers.A: <label>A. Both the mean and the median will be unchanged.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The median will be unchanged, but the mean will increase.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The median will be unchanged, but the mean will decrease.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The mean will be unchanged, but the median will increase.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Both the mean and median will change.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) The high outlier is further from the mean than is the low outlier, so removing both will decrease the mean. However, removing the lowest and highest values will not change what value is in the middle, so the median will be unchanged.

content: Suppose the average score on a national test is 500 with a standard deviation of 100. If each score is increased by 25, what are the new mean and standard deviation?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Adding the same constant to every value increases the mean by that same constant; however, the distances between the increased values and the increased mean stay the same, and so the standard deviation is unchanged. Graphically, you should picture the whole distribution as moving over by a constant; the mean moves, but the standard deviation (which measures spread) doesn't change.

content: Suppose the average score on a national test is 500 with a standard deviation of 100. If each score is increased by 25%, what are the new mean and standard deviation?
explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) Multiplying every value by the same constant multiplies both the mean and the standard deviation by that constant. Graphically, increasing each value by 25% (multiplying by 1.25) both moves and spreads out the distribution.

content:
If quartiles Q1 = 20 and Q3 = 30, which of the following must be true?

I.The median is 25.

II.The mean is between 20 and 30.

III.The standard deviation is at most 10.
explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) The median is somewhere between 20 and 30, but not necessarily at 25. Even a single very large score can result in a mean over 30 and a standard deviation over 10.

content: A 1995 poll by the Program for International Policy asked respondents what percentage of the U.S. budget they thought went to foreign aid. The mean response was 18%, and the median was 15%. (The actual amount is less than 1%.) What do these responses indicate about the likely shape of the distribution of all the responses?

answers.A: <label>A. The distribution is skewed to the left.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The distribution is skewed to the right.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The distribution is bell-shaped with a standard deviation of 3%.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The distribution is uniform between 15% and 18%.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) The median is less than the mean, and so the responses are probably skewed to the right; there are a few high guesses, with most of the responses on the lower end of the scale.

content:
Data on the number of text messages sent one weekend by junior and senior high school students in a large high school is summarized as follows:

An AP Statistics student checking the calculations finds that the message counts for all the students were underreported by 5. When the numbers are corrected, what are the corrected IQR and standard deviation?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Adding the same constant to every value will increase the Min, Q1, Median, Q3, Max, and Mean by that constant. However, measures of variability, including the IQR and the standard deviation, will remain unchanged.

content:
Which of the following are true statements?

I.If the sample has variance zero, the variance of the population is also zero.

II.If the population has variance zero, the variance of the sample is also zero.

III.If the sample has variance zero, the sample mean and the sample median are equal.

answers.E: <label>E. None of the above gives the complete set of true responses.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) If the variance of a set is zero, all the values in the set are equal. If all the values of the population are equal, the same holds true for any subset; however, if all the values of a subset are the same, this may not be true of the whole population. If all the values in a set are equal, the mean and the median both equal this common value and so equal each other.

content: When there are multiple gaps and clusters, which of the following is the best choice to give an overall picture of a distribution?

answers.E: <label>E. None of the above are really helpful in showing gaps and clusters.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Stemplots and histograms can show gaps and clusters that are hidden when one simply looks at calculations such as mean, median, standard deviation, quartiles, and extremes.

content:
Suppose the starting salaries of a graduating class are as follows:

What is the mean starting salary?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) There are a total of 10 + 17 + 25 + 38 + 27 + 21 + 12 = 150 students. Their total salary is 10(15,000) + 17(20,000) + 25(25,000) + 38(30,000) + 27(35,000) + 21(40,000) + 12(45,000) = $4,580,000. The mean is

content: When a set of data has suspect outliers, which of the following are preferred measures of central tendency and of variability?
explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) The mean, standard deviation, variance, and range are all affected by outliers; the median and interquartile range are not.

content: If the standard deviation of a set of observations is 0, you can conclude

answers.A: <label>A. that there is no relationship between the observations.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. that all observations are the same value.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. that a mistake in arithmetic has been made.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Because of the squaring operation in the definition, the standard deviation (and also the variance) can be zero only if all the values in the set are equal.

content: A teacher is teaching two AP Statistics classes. On the final exam, the 20 students in the first class averaged 92 while the 25 students in the second class averaged only 83. If the teacher combines the classes, what will the average final exam score be?

answers.E: <label>E. More information is needed to make this calculation.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) The sum of the scores in one class is 20 × 92 = 1840, while the sum in the other is 25 × 83 = 2075. The total sum is 1840 + 2075 = 3915. There are 20 + 25 = 45 students, and so the average score is

content: Suppose 10% of a data set lie between 40 and 60. If 5 is first added to each value in the set and then each result is doubled, which of the following is true?

answers.A: <label>A. 10% of the resulting data will lie between 85 and 125.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. 10% of the resulting data will lie between 90 and 130.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. 15% of the resulting data will lie between 80 and 120.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. 20% of the resulting data will lie between 45 and 65.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. 30% of the resulting data will lie between 85 and 125.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Increasing every value by 5 gives 10% between 45 and 65, and then doubling gives 10% between 90 and 130.

content: The 70 highest dams in the world have an average height of 206 meters with a standard deviation of 35 meters. The Hoover and Grand Coulee dams have heights of 221 and 168 meters, respectively. The Russian dams, the Nurek and Charvak, have heights with z-scores of +2.69 and -1.13, respectively. List the dams in order of ascending size.
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) 206 + 2.69(35) = 300; 206 - 1.13(35) = 166

content: The first 115 Kentucky Derby winners by color of horse were as follows: roan, 1; gray, 4; chestnut, 36; bay, 53; dark bay, 17; and black, 4. (You should "bet on the bay!") Which of the following visual displays is most appropriate?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Bar charts are used for categorical variables.

content:
For Question below considers the following: The graph below shows cumulative proportions plotted against grade point averages for a large public high school.

What is the median grade point average?

Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) The median corresponds to the 0.5 cumulative proportion.

content:
For Question below considers the following: The graph below shows cumulative proportions plotted against grade point averages for a large public high school.

What is the interquartile range?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) The 0.25 and 0.75 cumulative proportions correspond to Q1 = 1.8 and Q3 = 2.8, respectively, and so the interquartile range is 2.8 - 1.8 = 1.0.

content:
The following dotplot shows the speeds (in mph) of 100 fastballs thrown by a major league pitcher.

Which of the following is the best estimate of the standard deviation of these speeds?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) With bell-shaped data the empirical rule applies, giving that the spread from 92 to 98 is roughly 6 standard deviations, and so one SD is about 1.

content: Which of the following statements about the two histograms above is true?

answers.A: <label>A. The empirical rule applies only to set A.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The mean of set A looks to be greater than the mean of set B.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The mean of set B looks to be greater than the mean of set A.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Both sets have roughly the same variance.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The standard deviation of set B is greater than 5.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) The empirical rule applies to bell-shaped data like those found in set B, not in set A. Both sets are roughly symmetric around 150 and so both should have means about 150. Set A is much more spread out than set B, and so set A has the greater variance. For bell-shaped data, about 95% of the values fall within two standard deviations of the mean and 99.7% fall within three. However, in the histogram for set B, one sees that 95% of the data are not between 140 and 160, and 99.7% are not between 135 and 165. Thus, the standard deviation for set B must be greater than 5.

content:
Consider the following back-to-back stemplots comparing car battery lives (in months) of samples of two popular brands.

Which of the following are true statements?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Both sets have 20 elements. The ranges, 76-37 = 39 and 86-47 = 39, are equal. Brand A clearly has the larger mean and median, and with its skewness it also has the larger variance.

content:
The following boxplots were constructed from SAT math scores of boys and girls at a high school:

Which of the following is a possible boxplot for the combined scores of all the students?
explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) The minimum of the combined set of scores must be the min of the boys since it is lower; the maximum of the combined set of scores must be the max of the girls since it is higher; the first quartile must be the same as the identical first quartiles of the two original distributions. There are no outliers (scores more than 1.5(IQR) from the first and third quartiles).

content:
Question below refers to the following population pyramids (source: U.S. Census Bureau).

What is the approximate median age of the Liberian population?

answers.E: <label>E. There is insufficient information to approximate the median.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Roughly 50% of total bar length is above and below the 15-19 interval.

content:
Question below refers to the following population pyramids (source: U.S. Census Bureau).

Which country has more children younger than 10 years of age?

answers.C: <label>C. You can't tell without calculating means.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. You can't tell without calculating medians.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. You can't tell without calculating some measure of variability.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) There are about 1.2 million younger than the age of 10 in Liberia (boys and girls) and roughly 3.5 million in Canada.

content:
Question below refers to the following population pyramids (source: U.S. Census Bureau).

Which of the following statements are plausible, given the graphs?
explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) In the Canadian graph, all higher age groups show greater numbers of women than men. In the Liberian graph, the smaller 15-19 age group shows a definite break with the overall pattern (a great number of child soldiers died in the fighting). In the Canadian graph, the narrowing base indicates a decreasing birth rate.

content:
A study collects data on average combined SAT scores (math, critical reading, and writing) and percentage of students who took the exam at 100 randomly selected high schools. Following is part of the computer printout for regression:

Which of the following is a correct conclusion?

answers.A: <label>A. SAT in the variable column indicates that SAT is the dependent (response) variable.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The correlation is ±0.875, but the sign cannot be determined.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Schools with lower percentages of students taking the exam tend to have higher average combined SAT scores.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) The variable column indicates the independent (explanatory) variable. The sign of the correlation is the same as the sign of the slope (negative here). In this example, the y-intercept is meaningless (predicted SAT result if no students take the exam). There can be a strong linear relation, with high R2 value, but still a distinct pattern in the residual plot indicating that a non-linear fit may be even stronger. The negative value of the slope (-2.84276) gives that, on average, the predicted combined SAT score of a school is 2.84 points lower for each one unit higher in the percentage of students taking the exam.

content:
A simple random sample of 35 world-ranked chess players provides the following statistics:

Number of hours of study per day: = 6.2, sx = 1.3

Yearly winnings: = $208,000, sy = $42,000

Correlation r = 0.15

Based on this data, what is the resulting linear regression equation?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Slope = 0.15 ≈ 4850 and intercept = 208,000 - 4850(6.2) ≈ 178,000

content: A rural college is considering constructing a windmill to generate electricity but is concerned over noise levels. A study is performed measuring noise levels (in decibels) at various distances (in feet) from the campus library, and a least squares regression line is calculated with a correlation of 0.74. Which of the following is a proper and most informative conclusion for an observation with a negative residual?

answers.A: <label>A. The measured noise level is 0.74 times the predicted noise level.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The predicted noise level is 0.74 times the measured noise level.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The measured noise level is greater than the predicted noise level.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The predicted noise level is greater than the measured noise level.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The slope of the regression line at that point must also be negative.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Residual = Measured - Predicted, so if the residual is negative, the predicted must be greater than the measured (observed).

content:
Consider the following three scatterplots:

Which has the greatest correlation coefficient?

answers.D: <label>D. They all have the same correlation coefficient.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. This question cannot be answered without additional information.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) The correlation coefficient is not changed by adding the same number to each value of one of the variables or by multiplying each value of one of the variables by the same positive number.

content: Suppose the correlation is negative. Given two points from the scatterplot, which of the following is possible?
explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) A negative correlation shows a tendency for higher values of one variable to be associated with lower values of the other; however, given any two points, anything is possible.

content:
Consider the following residual plot:

Which of the following scatterplots could have resulted in the above residual plot? (The y-axis scales are not the same in the scatterplots as in the residual plot.)

answers.E: <label>E. None of these could result in the given residual plot.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) This is the only scatterplot in which the residuals go from positive to negative and back to positive.

content: Suppose the regression line for a set of data, = 3x + b, passes through the point (2, 5). If and are the sample means of the x- and y-values, respectively, then =
explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) Since (2, 5) is on the line y = 3x + b, we have 5 = 6 + b and b = -1. Thus the regression line is y = 3x - 1. The point (, ) is always on the regression line, and so we have = 3 - 1.

content: Suppose a study finds that the correlation coefficient relating family income to SAT scores is r = +1. Which of the following are proper conclusions?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) The correlation r measures association, not causation.

content: A study of department chairperson ratings and student ratings of the performance of high school statistics teachers reports a correlation of r = 1.15 between the two ratings. From this information we can conclude that

answers.A: <label>A. chairpersons and students tend to agree on who is a good teacher.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. chairpersons and students tend to disagree on who is a good teacher.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. there is little relationship between chairperson and student ratings of teachers.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. there is strong association between chairperson and student ratings of teachers, but it would be incorrect to infer causation.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. a mistake in arithmetic has been made.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) The correlation r cannot take a value greater than 1.

content: Which of the following statements about correlation r is true?

answers.A: <label>A. A correlation of 0.2 means that 20% of the points are highly correlated.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Correlation is not affected by extreme values.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. A correlation of 0.75 indicates a relationship that is 3 times as linear as one for which the correlation is only 0.25.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) If the points lie on a straight line, r = Â±1. Correlation has the formula so x and y are interchangeable, and r does not depend on which variable is called x or y. However, since means and standard deviations can be strongly influenced by outliers, r too can be strongly affected by extreme values. While r = 0.75 indicates a better fit with a linear model than r = 0.25 does, we cannot say that the linearity is threefold.

content:
Question below refers to the following:

The relationship between winning game proportions when facing the sun and when the sun is on one's back is analyzed for a random sample of 10 professional tennis players. The computer printout for regression is below:

What is the equation of the regression line, where facing and back are the winning game proportions when facing the sun and with back to the sun, respectively?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

(B) The "Predictor" column indicates the independent variable with its coefficient to the right.

content:
Question below refers to the following:

The relationship between winning game proportions when facing the sun and when the sun is on one's back is analyzed for a random sample of 10 professional tennis players. The computer printout for regression is below:

What is the correlation?
explanation:

content:
Question below refers to the following:

The relationship between winning game proportions when facing the sun and when the sun is on one's back is analyzed for a random sample of 10 professional tennis players. The computer printout for regression is below:

For one player, the winning game proportions were 0.55 and 0.59 for facing and back, respectively. What was the associated residual?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) = 0.056 + 0.920 (0.55) = 0.562 and so the residual = 0.59 - 0.562 = 0.028

content: Which of the following statements about residuals from the least squares line are true?

answers.E: <label>E. None of the above gives the complete set of true responses.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) The sum and thus the mean of the residuals are always zero. In a good straight-line fit, the residuals show a random pattern.

content:
Data are obtained for a group of college freshmen examining their SAT scores (math plus writing plus critical reading) from their senior year of high school and their GPAs during their first year of college. The resulting regression equation is

= 0.55 + 0.00161 (SAT total) with r = 0.632

What percentage of the variation in GPAs can be explained by looking at the linear relationship between GPAs and SAT scores?

answers.E: <label>E. This value cannot be computed from the information given.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) The coefficient of determination r2 gives the proportion of the y-variance that is predictable from a knowledge of x. In this case r2 = (0.632)2 = 0.399 or 39.9%.

content:
In a study of whether the structure of the adult human brain changes when a new skill is learned, the gray matter volume of four individuals was measured before and after learning a new cognitive skill. The resulting scatterplot was:

The correlation above is 0. Three researchers each run the experiment on a new subject and each obtain an additional data point:

Match the above scatterplots with their new correlations.
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) The point I doesn't contribute to a line with negative or positive slope. In none of the scatterplots do the points fall on a straight line, so none of them have correlation 1.0.

content:
In a study of winning percentage in home games versus average home attendance for professional baseball teams, the resulting regression line is:

What is the residual if a team has a winning percentage of 55% with an average attendance of 34,000?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Predicted winning percentage = 44 + 0.0003(34,000) = 54.2, and

Residual = Observed - Predicted = 55 - 54.2 = 0.8.

content:
Consider the following scatterplot of midterm and final exam scores for a class of 15 students.

Which of the following is incorrect?

answers.A: <label>A. The same number of students scored 100 on the midterm exam as scored 100 on the final exam.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Students who scored higher on the midterm exam tended to score higher on the final exam.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The scatterplot shows a moderate negative correlation between midterm and final exam scores.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The coefficient of determination here is positive.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. No one scored 90 or above on both exams.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) On each exam, two students had scores of 100. There is a general negative slope to the data showing a moderate negative correlation. The coefficient of determination, r2, is always â‰¥ 0. While several students scored 90 or above on one or the other exam, no student did so on both exams.

content: If every woman married a man who was exactly 2 inches taller than she, what would the correlation between the heights of married men and women be?
explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) On the scatterplot all the points lie perfectly on a line sloping up to the right, and so r = 1.

content: Suppose the correlation between two variables is r = 0.23. What will the new correlation be if 0.14 is added to all values of the x-variable, every value of the y-variable is doubled, and the two variables are interchanged?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) The correlation is not changed by adding the same number to every value of one of the variables, by multiplying every value of one of the variables by the same positive number, or by interchanging the x- and y-variables.

content: Suppose the correlation between two variables is -0.57. If each of the y-scores is multiplied by -1, which of the following is true about the new scatterplot?

answers.A: <label>A. It slopes up to the right, and the correlation is -0.57.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. It slopes up to the right, and the correlation is +0.57.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. It slopes down to the right, and the correlation is -0.57.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. It slopes down to the right, and the correlation is +0.57.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. None of the above is true.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) The slope and the correlation coefficient have the same sign. Multiplying every y-value by -1 changes this sign.

content: Consider the set of points {(2, 5), (3, 7), (4, 9), (5, 12), (10, n)}. What should n be so that the correlation between the x- and y-values is 1?

answers.D: <label>D. A value different from any of the above.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) A scatterplot readily shows that while the first three points lie on a straight line, the fourth point does not lie on this line. Thus no matter what the fifth point is, all the points cannot lie on a straight line, and so r cannot be 1.

content: Which of the following scatterplots is from data with a correlation coefficient closest to 0?
explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) The correlation coefficient measures the strength of a linear association.

content: Consider the three points (2, 11), (3, 17), and (4, 29). Given any straight line, we can calculate the sum of the squares of the three vertical distances from these points to the line. What is the smallest possible value this sum can be?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Using your calculator, find the regression line to be = 9x - 8. The regression line, also called the least squares regression line, minimizes the sum of the squares of the vertical distances between the points and the line. In this case (2, 10), (3, 19), and (4, 28) are on the line, and so the minimum sum is (10 - 11)2 + (19 - 17)2 + (28 - 29)2 = 6.

content: Suppose that the scatterplot of log X and log Y shows a strong positive correlation close to 1. Which of the following is true?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) When transforming the variables leads to a linear relationship, the original variables have a nonlinear relationship, their correlation (which measures linearity) is not close to 1, and the residuals do not show a random pattern. While r close to 1 indicates strong association, it does not indicate cause and effect.

content: Consider n pairs of numbers. Suppose = 2, sx = 3, = 4, and sy = 5. Of the following, which could be the least squares line?
explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) The least squares line passes through (, ) = (2, 4), and the slope b satisfies .

content:
Question below is based on the following: To study the relationship between party affiliation and support for a balanced budget amendment, 500 registered voters were surveyed with the following results:

What percentage of those surveyed were Democrats?
explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) Of the 500 people surveyed, 50 + 150 + 50 = 250 were Democrats, and = 0.5 or 50%.

content:
Question below is based on the following: To study the relationship between party affiliation and support for a balanced budget amendment, 500 registered voters were surveyed with the following results:

What percentage of those surveyed were for the amendment and were Republicans?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Of the 500 people surveyed, 125 were both for the amendment and Republicans, and = 0.25 or 25%.

content:
Question below is based on the following: To study the relationship between party affiliation and support for a balanced budget amendment, 500 registered voters were surveyed with the following results:

What percentage of Independents had no opinion?
explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) There were 15 + 10 + 25 = 50 Independents; 25 of them had no opinion, and = 0.5 or 50%.

content:
Question below is based on the following: To study the relationship between party affiliation and support for a balanced budget amendment, 500 registered voters were surveyed with the following results:

What percentage of those against the amendment were Democrats?
explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) There were 150 + 50 + 10 = 210 people against the amendment; 150 of them were Democrats, and = 0.714 or 71.4%.

content:
Question below is based on the following: To study the relationship between party affiliation and support for a balanced budget amendment, 500 registered voters were surveyed with the following results:

Voters of which affiliation were most likely to have no opinion about the amendment?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) The percentages of Democrats, Republicans, and Independents with no opinion are 20%, 12.5%, and 50%, respectively.

content:
Question below is based on the following: A study of music preferences in three geographic locations resulted in the following segmented bar chart:

What percentage of those surveyed from the Northeast prefer country music?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) In the bar corresponding to the Northeast, the segment corresponding to country music stretches from the 50% level to the 70% level, indicating a length of 20%.

content:
Question below is based on the following: A study of music preferences in three geographic locations resulted in the following segmented bar chart:

Which of the following is greatest?

answers.A: <label>A. The percentage of those from the Northeast who prefer classical.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The percentage of those from the West who prefer country.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The percentage of those from the South who prefer pop or rock.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. It is impossible to determine the answer without knowing the actual numbers of people involved.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Based on lengths of indicated segments, the percentage from the West who prefer country is the greatest.

content:
Question below is based on the following: A study of music preferences in three geographic locations resulted in the following segmented bar chart:

Which of the following is greatest?

answers.A: <label>A. The number of people in the Northeast who prefer pop or rock.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The number of people in the West who prefer classical.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The number of people in the South who prefer country.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. It is impossible to determine the answer without knowing the actual numbers of people involved.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) The given bar chart shows percentages, not actual numbers.

content:
Question below is based on the following: A study of music preferences in three geographic locations resulted in the following segmented bar chart:

All three bars have a height of 100%. Which of the following is true?

answers.B: <label>B. This happened because each bar shows a complete distribution.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. This happened because there are three bars each divided into three segments.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. This happened because of the nature of musical patterns.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. None of the above is true.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) In a complete distribution, the probabilities sum to 1, and the relative frequencies total 100%.

content:
Question below is based on the following: A study of music preferences in three geographic locations resulted in the following segmented bar chart:

Based on the given segmented bar chart, does there seem to be a relationship between geographic location and music preference?

answers.A: <label>A. Yes, because the corresponding segments of the three bars have different lengths.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Yes, because the heights of the three bars are identical.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Yes, because there are three segments and three bars.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. No, because the heights of the three bars are identical.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. No, because summing the corresponding segments for classical, summing the corresponding segments for country, and summing the corresponding segments for pop or rock all give approximately the same total.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) The different lengths of corresponding segments show that in different geographic regions different percentages of people prefer each of the music categories.

content: In the following table, what value for n results in a table showing perfect independence?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Relative frequencies must be equal. Either looking at rows gives or looking at columns gives . We could also set up a proportion or . Solving any of these equations gives n = 75.

content: A company employs both men and women in its secretarial and executive positions. In reports filed with the government, the company shows that the percentage of female employees who receive raises is higher than the percentage of male employees who receive raises. A government investigator claims that the percentage of male secretaries who receive raises is higher than the percentage of female secretaries who receive raises, and that the percentage of male executives who receive raises is higher than the percentage of female executives who receive raises. Is this possible?

answers.A: <label>A. No, either the company report is wrong or the investigator's claim is wrong.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. No, if the company report is correct, then either a greater percentage of female secretaries than of male secretaries receive raises or a greater percentage of female executives than of male executives receive raises.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. No, if the investigator is correct, then by summation of the corresponding numbers, the total percentage of male employees who receive raises would have to be greater than the total percentage of female employees who receive raises.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. All of the above are true.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. It is possible for both the company report to be true and the investigator's claim to be correct.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) It is possible for both to be correct, for example, if there were 11 secretaries (10 women, 3 of whom receive raises, and 1 man who receives a raise) and 11 executives (10 men, 1 of whom receives a raise, and 1 woman who does not receive a raise). Then 100% of the male secretaries receive raises while only 30% of the female secretaries do; and 10% of the male executives receive raises while 0% of the female executives do. However, overall 3 out of 11 women receive raises, while only 2 out of 11 men receive raises. This is an example of Simpson's paradox.

content: A school psychologist wants to investigate student depression. She selects, at random, samples of 30 freshmen, 30 sophomores, 30 juniors, and 30 seniors to interview. Which of the following best describes the principal's sampling plan?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) The four classes (freshmen, sophomores, juniors, and seniors) are strata.

content: Which of the following is a true statement?

answers.A: <label>A. If bias is present in a sampling procedure, it can be overcome by dramatically increasing the sample size.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. There is no such thing as a "bad sample."</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Sampling techniques that use probability techniques effectively eliminate bias.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Convenience samples often lead to undercoverage bias.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Voluntary response samples often underrepresent people with strong opinions.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) If there is bias, taking a larger sample just magnifies the bias on a larger scale. If there is enough bias, the sample can be worthless. Even when the subjects are chosen randomly, there can be bias due, for example, to non-response or to the wording of the questions. Convenience samples, like shopping mall surveys, are based on choosing individuals who are easy to reach, and they typically miss a large segment of the population. Voluntary response samples, like radio call-in surveys, are based on individuals who offer to participate, and they typically overrepresent persons with strong opinions.

content: Which of the following is a true statement about sampling error?

answers.A: <label>A. Sampling error can be eliminated only if a survey is both extremely well designed and extremely well conducted.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Sampling error concerns natural variation between samples, is always present, and can be described using probability.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Sampling error is generally larger when the sample size is larger.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Sampling error implies an error, possibly very small, but still an error, on the part of the surveyor.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Sampling error is higher when bias is present.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Different samples give different sample statistics, all of which are estimates of a population parameter. Sampling error relates to natural variation between samples, can never be eliminated, can be described using probability, and is generally smaller if the sample size is larger.

content: Many colleges are moving toward coed dormitories. A Residential Life director plans to sample student attitudes toward this arrangement. He randomly selects three of the 12 dorms and sends a questionnaire to all residents living in them. Which of the following best describes the director's sampling plan?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) The dorms are clusters.

content: Ann Landers, who wrote a daily advice column appearing in newspapers across the country, once asked her readers, "If you had it to do over again, would you have children?" Of the more than 10,000 readers who responded, 70% said no. What does this show?

answers.A: <label>A. The survey is meaningless because of voluntary response bias.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. No meaningful conclusion is possible without knowing something more about the characteristics of her readers.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The survey would have been more meaningful if she had picked a random sample of the 10,000 readers who responded.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The survey would have been more meaningful if she had used a control group.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. This was a legitimate sample, randomly drawn from her readers and of sufficient size to allow the conclusion that most of her readers who are parents would have second thoughts about having children.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) This survey provides a good example of voluntary response bias, which often overrepresents negative opinions. The people who chose to respond were most likely parents who were very unhappy, and so there is very little chance that the 10,000 respondents were representative of the population. Knowing more about her readers, or taking a sample of the sample, would not have helped.

content: Each of the 30 MLB teams has 25 active roster players. A sample of 60 players is to be chosen as follows. Each team will be asked to place 25 cards with its players' names into a hat and randomly draw out two names. The two names from each team will be combined to make up the sample. Will this method result in a simple random sample of the 750 baseball players?

answers.A: <label>A. Yes, because each player has the same chance of being selected.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Yes, because each team is equally represented.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Yes, because this is an example of stratified sampling, which is a special case of simple random sampling.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. No, because the teams are not chosen randomly.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. No, because not each group of 60 players has the same chance of being selected.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) In a simple random sample, every possible group of the given size has to be equally likely to be selected, and this is not true here. For example, with this procedure it would be impossible for all the Cubs to be together in the final sample. This procedure is an example of stratified sampling, but stratified sampling does not result in simple random samples.

content: To evaluate their catering service with regard to culinary excellence, airline executives plan to pick a random passenger to start with and then survey every tenth passenger departing from a Beijing to San Francisco flight. Which of the following best describes the executives' sampling plan?
explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) With a random starting point and by picking every nth person for the sample, the method is called systematic sampling.

content:
School uniforms are being adopted by U.S. public schools in increasing numbers. Two possible wordings for a question on whether or not students should have to wear school uniforms are as follows:

I.Many educators believe in creating a level playing field to reduce socioeconomic disparities. Do you believe that students should have to wear school uniforms?

II.Many sociologists believe that students have a right to express their individuality. Do you believe that students should have to wear school uniforms?

One of these questions showed that 18% of the population favors school uniforms, while the other question showed that 23% of the population favors school uniforms. Which question probably produced which result and why?

answers.A: <label>A. The first question probably showed 23% of the population favors school uniforms, and the second question probably showed 18% because of the lack of randomization in the choice of pro-uniform and anti-uniform arguments as evidenced by the wording of the questions.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The first question probably showed 18% and the second question probably showed 23% because of stratification in the wording of the questions.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The first question probably showed 23% and the second question probably showed 18% because of the lack of a neutral cluster in the sample.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The first question probably showed 18% and the second question probably showed 23% because of response bias due to the wording of the questions.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The first question probably showed 23% and the second question probably showed 18% because of response bias due to the wording of the questions.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) The wording "creating a level playing field " and "a right to express their individuality" are nonneutral and clearly leading phrasings.

content: In a study of successes and failures in adopting Common Core standards, a random sample of high school principals will be selected from each of the 50 states. Selected individuals will be asked a series of evaluative questions. Why is stratification used here?

answers.D: <label>D. Because each state is roughly representative of the U.S. population as a whole</label>
answers.E: <label>E. To obtain higher statistical precision because variability of responses within a state is likely less than variability of responses found in the overall population</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) Each of the 50 states, with its own long-time past state standards and different regional culture, is considered a homogeneous stratum.

content: In order to minimize response bias, which of these design elements is most important?

answers.C: <label>C. Increasing the length of the survey</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Response bias, occurring when the question itself can lead to misleading results because people don't want to be perceived as having unpopular or unsavory views, has nothing to do with sample size, randomization, or length of the survey. The only reasonable answer suggests pilot testing, which could have brought to light the problem.

content: The number of surveys being conducted over the Internet has been increasing dramatically. Which of the following is NOT true about such surveys?

answers.A: <label>A. Low cost compared to most other types of surveys</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Convenience of respondents to take the survey at their own time and own pace</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Less response bias than associated with interviewer-administered modes</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Allows for the use of multimedia elements not available to other survey modes</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) There can be significant nonresponse bias as a large fraction of those who see a pop-up online survey do not bother responding. There can also be significant undercoverage bias as not everyone in the U.S. has access to the Internet. There are also significant demographic differences between those who do have access and those who do not.

content: To find out the average occupancy size of student-rented apartments, a researcher picks a simple random sample of 100 such apartments. Even after one follow-up visit, the interviewer is unable to make contact with anyone in 27 of these apartments. Concerned about nonresponse bias, the researcher chooses another simple random sample and instructs the interviewer to continue this procedure until contact is made with someone in a total of 100 apartments. The average occupancy size in the final 100-apartment sample is 2.78. Is this estimate probably too low or too high?

answers.A: <label>A. Too low, because of undercoverage bias.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Too low, because convenience samples overestimate average results.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Too high, because of undercoverage bias.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Too high, because convenience samples overestimate average results.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Too high, because voluntary response samples overestimate average results.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) It is most likely that the apartments at which the interviewer had difficulty finding someone home were apartments with fewer students living in them. Replacing these with other randomly picked apartments most likely replaces smaller-occupancy apartments with larger-occupancy ones.

content: A researcher planning a survey of heads of households in a particular state has census lists for each of the 23 counties in that state. The procedure will be to obtain a random sample of heads of households from each of the counties rather than grouping all the census lists together and obtaining a sample from the entire group. Which of the following is an incorrect statement about the resulting stratified sample?

answers.A: <label>A. It is not a simple random sample.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. It is easier and less costly to obtain than a simple random sample.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. It gives comparative information that a simple random sample wouldn't give.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. A cluster sample would have been more appropriate.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Differences in county sizes could be taken into account by making the size of the random sample from each county depend on the proportion of the total population represented by the county.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) This is not a simple random sample because all possible sets of the required size do not have the same chance of being picked. For example, a set of households all from just half the counties has no chance of being picked to be the sample. Stratified samples are often easier and less costly to obtain and also make comparative data available. In this case responses can be compared among various counties. There is no reason to assume that each county has heads of households with the same characteristics and opinions as the state as a whole, so cluster sampling is not appropriate. When conducting stratified sampling, proportional sampling is used when one wants to take into account the different sizes of the strata.

content: To survey the opinions of bleacher fans at Wrigley Field, a surveyor plans to select every one-hundredth fan entering the bleachers one afternoon. Will this result in a simple random sample of Cub fans who sit in the bleachers?

answers.A: <label>A. Yes, because each bleacher fan has the same chance of being selected.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Yes, but only if there is a single entrance to the bleachers.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Yes, because the 99 out of 100 bleacher fans who are not selected will form a control group.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Yes, because this is an example of systematic sampling, which is a special case of simple random sampling.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. No, because not every sample of the intended size has an equal chance of being selected.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) In a simple random sample, every possible group of the given size has to be equally likely to be selected, and this is not true here. For example, with this procedure it will be impossible for all the early arrivals to be together in the final sample. This procedure is an example of systematic sampling, but systematic sampling does not result in simple random samples.

content: A researcher plans a study to examine the depth of belief in God among the adult population. He obtains a simple random sample of 100 adults as they leave church one Sunday morning. All but one of them agree to participate in the survey. Which of the following is a true statement?

answers.A: <label>A. Proper use of chance as evidenced by the simple random sample makes this a well-designed survey.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The high response rate makes this a well-designed survey.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Selection bias makes this a poorly designed survey.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The validity of this survey depends on whether or not the adults attending this church are representative of all churches.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The validity of this survey depends upon whether or not similar numbers of those surveyed are male and female.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Surveying people coming out of any church results in a very unrepresentative sample of the adult population, especially given the question under consideration. Using chance and obtaining a high response rate will not change the selection bias and make this into a well-designed survey.

content: Suppose you wish to compare the average class size of mathematics classes to the average class size of English classes in your high school. Which is the most appropriate technique for gathering the needed data?

answers.E: <label>E. None of these methods is appropriate.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) The main office at your school should be able to give you the class sizes of every math and English class. If need be, you can check with every math and English teacher.

content: Two studies are run to compare the experiences of families living in high-rise public housing to those of families living in townhouse subsidized rentals. The first study interviews 25 families who have been in each government program for at least 1 year, while the second randomly assigns 25 families to each program and interviews them after 1 year. Which of the following is a true statement?

answers.A: <label>A. Both studies are observational studies because of the time period involved.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Both studies are observational studies because there are no control groups.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The first study is an observational study, while the second is an experiment.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The first study is an experiment, while the second is an observational study.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) In the first study the families were already in the housing units, while in the second study one of two treatments was applied to each family.

content: Two studies are run to determine the effect of low levels of wine consumption on cholesterol level. The first study measures the cholesterol levels of 100 volunteers who have not consumed alcohol in the past year and compares these values with their cholesterol levels after 1 year, during which time each volunteer drinks one glass of wine daily. The second study measures the cholesterol levels of 100 volunteers who have not consumed alcohol in the past year, randomly picks half the group to drink one glass of wine daily for a year while the others drink no alcohol for the year, and finally measures their levels again. Which of the following is a true statement?

answers.A: <label>A. The first study is an observational study, while the second is an experiment.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The first study is an experiment, while the second is an observational study.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Both studies are observational studies, but only one uses both randomization and a control group.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The first study is a census of 100 volunteers, while the second study is an experiment.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) Both studies apply treatments and measure responses, and so both are experiments.

content: A study is made to determine whether taking AP Statistics in high school helps students achieve higher GPAs when they go to college. In comparing records of 200 college students, half of whom took AP Statistics in high school, it is noted that the average college GPA is higher for those 100 students who took AP Statistics than for those who did not. Based on this study, guidance counselors begin recommending AP Statistics for college bound students. Which of the following is incorrect?

answers.A: <label>A. While this study indicates a relation, it does not prove causation.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. There could well be a confounding variable responsible for the seeming relationship.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Self-selection here makes drawing the counselors' conclusion difficult.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. A more meaningful study would be to compare an SRS from each of the two groups of 100 students.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. This is an observational study, not an experiment.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) It may well be that very bright students are the same ones who both take AP Statistics and have high college GPAs. If students could be randomly assigned to take or not take AP Statistics, the results would be more meaningful. Of course, ethical considerations might make it impossible to isolate the confounding variable in this way. Only using a sample from the observations gives less information.

content: In a 1927-1932 Western Electric Company study on the effect of lighting on worker productivity, productivity increased with each increase in lighting but then also increased with every decrease in lighting. If it is assumed that the workers knew a study was in progress, this is an example of

answers.A: <label>A. the effect of a treatment unit.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) The desire of the workers for the study to be successful led to a placebo effect.

content: When the estrogen-blocking drug tamoxifen was first introduced to treat breast cancer, there was concern that it would cause osteoporosis as a side effect. To test this concern, cancer subjects were randomly selected and given tamoxifen, and their bone density was measured before and after treatment. Which of the following is a true statement?

answers.A: <label>A. This study was an observational study.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. This study was a sample survey of randomly selected cancer patients.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. This study was an experiment in which the subjects were used as their own controls.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. With the given procedure, there cannot be a placebo effect.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Causation cannot be concluded without knowing the survival rates.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) In experiments on people, the subjects can be used as their own controls, with responses noted before and after the treatment. However, with such designs there is always the danger of a placebo effect. Thus the design of choice would involve a separate control group to be used for comparison.

content: In designing an experiment, blocking is used

answers.C: <label>C. as a substitute for a control group.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. as a first step in randomization.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. to control the level of the experiment.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Blocking divides the subjects into groups, such as men and women, or political affiliations, and thus reduces variation.

content: Which of the following is incorrect?

answers.A: <label>A. Blocking is to experiment design as stratification is to sampling design.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. By controlling certain variables, blocking can make conclusions more specific.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The paired comparison design is a special case of blocking.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Blocking results in increased accuracy because the blocks have smaller size than the original group.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. In a randomized block design, the randomization occurs within the blocks.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Blocking in experiment design first divides the subjects into representative groups called blocks, just as stratification in sampling design first divides the population into representative groups called strata. This procedure can control certain variables by bringing them directly into the picture, and thus conclusions are more specific. The paired comparison design is a special case of blocking in which each pair can be considered a block. Unnecessary blocking detracts from accuracy because of smaller sample sizes.

content:
Consider the following studies being run by three different nursing home establishments.

I.One nursing home has pets brought in for an hour every day to see if patient morale is improved.

II.One nursing home allows hourly visits every day by kindergarten children to see if patient morale is improved.

III.One nursing home administers antidepressants to all patients to see if patient morale is improved.

Which of the following is true?

answers.A: <label>A. None of these studies uses randomization.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. None of these studies uses control groups.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. None of these studies uses blinding.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Important information can be obtained from all these studies, but none will be able to establish causal relationships.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) None of the studies has any controls, such as randomization, control groups, or blinding, and so while they may give valuable information, they cannot establish cause and effect.

content: A consumer product agency tests miles per gallon for a sample of automobiles using each of four different octanes of gasoline. Which of the following is true?

answers.A: <label>A. There are four explanatory variables and one response variable.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. There is one explanatory variable with four levels of response.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Miles per gallon is the only explanatory variable, but there are four response variables corresponding to the different octanes.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. There are four levels of a single explanatory variable.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Each explanatory level has an associated level of response.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Octane is the only explanatory variable, and it is being tested at four levels. Miles per gallon is the single response variable.

content: Is hot oatmeal with fruit or a Western omelet with home fries a more satisfying breakfast? Fifty volunteers are randomly split into two groups. One group is fed oatmeal with fruit, while the other is fed Western omelets with home fries. Each volunteer then rates his/her breakfast on a one to ten scale for satisfaction. If the Western omelet with home fries receives a substantially higher average score, what is a reasonable conclusion?

answers.A: <label>A. In general, people find Western omelets with home fries more satisfying for breakfast than hot oatmeal with fruit.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. There is no reasonable conclusion because the subjects were volunteering rather than being randomly selected from the general population.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. There is no reasonable conclusion because of the small size of the sample.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. There is no reasonable conclusion because blinding was not used.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. There is no reasonable conclusion because there are too many possible confounding variables such as age, race, and ethnic background of the individual volunteers and season when the study was performed.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) There is nothing wrong with using volunteers—what is important is to randomly assign the volunteers into the two treatment groups. There is no way to use blinding in this study—the subjects will clearly know which breakfast they are eating. The main idea behind randomly assigning subjects to the different treatments is to control for various possible confounding variables—it is reasonable to assume that people of various ages, races, ethnic backgrounds, etc., are assigned to receive each of the treatments.

content: Which of the following is not true?

answers.A: <label>A. In an experiment some treatment is intentionally forced on one group to note the response.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. In an observational study information is gathered on an already existing situation.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Sample surveys are observational studies, not experiments.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. While observational studies may suggest relationships, it is usually not possible to conclude cause and effect because of the lack of control over possible confounding variables.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. A complete census is the only way to establish a cause-and-effect relationship absolutely.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) The first two sentences can be considered part of the definitions of experiment and observational study. A sample survey does not impose any treatment; it simply counts a certain outcome, and so it is an observational study, not an experiment. A complete census can provide much information about a population, but it doesn't necessarily establish a cause-and-effect relationship among seemingly related population parameters.

content: Which of the following is not important in the design of experiments?

answers.B: <label>B. Randomization in assigning subjects to different treatments</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Replication of the experiment using sufficient numbers of subjects</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Care in observing without imposing change</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Isolating variability due to differences between blocks</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Control, randomization, and replication are all important aspects of well-designed experiments. Care in observing without imposing change refers to observational studies, not experiments.

content: Which of the following is a true statement about the design of matched-pair experiments?

answers.A: <label>A. Each subject might receive both treatments.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Each pair of subjects receives the identical treatment, and differences in their responses are noted.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Blocking is one form of matched-pair design.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Stratification into two equal sized strata is an example of matched pairs.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Randomization is unnecessary in true matched pair designs.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Each subject might receive both treatments, as, for example, in the Pepsi-Coke taste comparison study. The point is to give each subject in a matched pair a different treatment and note any difference in responses. Matched-pair experiments are a particular example of blocking, not vice versa. Stratification refers to a sampling method, not to experimental design. Randomization is used to decide which of a pair gets which treatment or which treatment is given first if one subject is to receive both.

content: Do teenagers prefer sports drinks colored blue or green? Two different colorings, which have no effect on taste, are used on the identical drink to result in a blue and a green beverage; volunteer teenagers are randomly assigned to drink one or the other colored beverage; and the volunteers then rate the beverage on a one to ten scale. Because of concern that sports interest may affect the outcome, the volunteers are first blocked by whether or not they play on a high school team. Is blinding possible in this experiment?

answers.A: <label>A. No, because the volunteers know whether they are drinking a blue or green drink.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. No, because the volunteers know whether or not they play on a high school team.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Yes, by having the experimenter in a separate room randomly pick one of two containers and remotely have a drink poured from that container.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Yes, by having the statistician analyzing the results not knowing which volunteer sampled which drink.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Yes, by having the volunteers drink out of solid colored thermoses, so that they don't know the color of the drink they are tasting.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Blinding does have to do with whether or not the subjects know which treatment (color in this experiment) they are receiving. However, drinking out of solid colored thermoses makes no sense since the beverages are identical except for color and the point of the experiment is the teenager's reaction to color. Blinding has nothing to do with blocking (team participation in this experiment).

content: Some researchers believe that too much iron in the blood can raise the level of cholesterol. The iron level in the blood can be lowered by making periodic blood donations. A study is performed by randomly selecting half of a group of volunteers to give periodic blood donations while the rest do not. Is this an experiment or an observational study?

answers.A: <label>A. An experiment with a single factor</label>
answers.B: <label>B. An experiment with control group and blinding</label>
answers.D: <label>D. An observational study with comparison and randomization</label>
answers.E: <label>E. An observational study with little, if any, bias</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) This study is an experiment because a treatment (periodic removal of a pint of blood) is imposed. There is no blinding because the subjects clearly know whether or not they are giving blood. There is no blocking because the subjects are not divided into blocks before random assignment to treatments. For example, blocking would have been used if the subjects had been separated by gender or age before random assignment to give or not give blood donations. There is a single factorâ€”giving or not giving blood.

content: A student reasons that either he will or will not receive a 5 on the AP Statistics exam, and therefore the probability of receiving a 5 is 0.5. Why is this incorrect reasoning?

answers.E: <label>E. The events are not equally probable.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) There is no reason to assume that the probability of getting a 5 is the same as that of not getting a 5.

content: In the November 27, 1994, issue of Parade magazine, the "Ask Marilyn" section contained this question: "Suppose a person was having two surgeries performed at the same time. If the chances of success for surgery A are 85%, and the chances of success for surgery B are 90%, what are the chances that both would fail?" What do you think of Marilyn's solution: (0.15)(0.10) = 0.015 or 1.5%?

answers.A: <label>A. Her solution is mathematically correct but not explained very well.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Her solution is both mathematically correct and intuitively obvious.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Her use of complementary events is incorrect.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Her use of the general addition formula is incorrect.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. She assumed independence of events, which is most likely wrong.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) The probability that both events will occur is the product of their separate probabilities only if the events are independent, that is, only if the chance that one event will happen is not influenced by whether or not the second event happens. In this case the probability of different surgeries failing are probably closely related.

content: In a 1974 "Dear Abby" letter a woman lamented that she had just given birth to her eighth child, and all were girls! Her doctor had assured her that the chance of the eighth child being a girl was only 1 in 100. What was the real probability that the eighth child would be a girl?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) The probability of the next child being a girl is independent of the gender of the previous children.

content: The yearly mortality rate for American men from prostate cancer has been constant for decades at about 25 of every 100,000 men. (This rate has not changed in spite of new diagnostic techniques and new treatments.) In a group of 100 American men, what is the probability that at least 1 will die from prostate cancer in a given year?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) The probability of dying from prostate cancer is 0.00025, so the probability of not dying of prostate cancer is 1 - 0.00025 = 0.99975. The probability of all 100 men not dying from prostate cancer is (0.99975)100. The complement, that is the probability of at least one man dying of prostate cancer, is 1 - (0.99975)100.

content: Alan Dershowitz, one of O. J. Simpson's lawyers, has stated that only 1 out of every 1000 abusive relationships ends in murder each year. If he is correct, and if there are approximately 1.5 million abusive relationships in the United States, what is the expected value for the number of people who are killed each year by an abusive partner?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) 0.001(1,500,000) = 1500

content: Suppose that among the 6000 students at a high school, 1500 are taking honors courses and 1800 prefer watching basketball to watching football. If taking honors courses and preferring basketball are independent, how many students are both taking honors courses and prefer basketball to football?

answers.E: <label>E. There is insufficient information to answer this question.</label>

explanation:

Explanation:

(C) are honors students, and prefer basketball. Because of independence, their intersection is (0.25)(0.3) = 0.075 of the students, and 0.075(6000) = 450.

content: An inspection procedure at a manufacturing plant involves picking three items at random and then accepting the whole lot if at least two of the three items are in perfect condition. If in reality 90% of the whole lot are perfect, what is the probability that the lot will be accepted?
explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) This is a binomial with n = 3 and p = 0.90. Then P(X â‰¥ 2) = (0.9)3 + 3(0.9)2(0.1).

content: Suppose that, for any given year, the probabilities that the stock market declines, that women's hemlines are lower, and that both events occur are, respectively, 0.4, 0.35, and 0.3. Are the two events independent?

answers.E: <label>E. There is insufficient information to answer this question.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) If E and F are independent, then P(E ∩ F) = P(E)P(F); however, in this problem, (0.4)(0.35) ≠ 0.3.

content: If P(A) = 0.2 and P(B) = 0.1, what is P(A ∪ B) if A and B are independent?

answers.A: <label>A. There is insufficient information to answer this question.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Because A and B are independent, we have P(A ∩ B) = P(A)P(B), and thus P(A ∪ B) = 0.2 + 0.1 - (0.2)(0.1).

content: There are two games involving flipping a coin. In the first game you win a prize if you can throw between 40% and 60% heads. In the second game you win if you can throw more than 75% heads. For each game would you rather flip the coin 50 times or 500 times?

answers.C: <label>C. 50 times for the first game, and 500 for the second</label>
answers.D: <label>D. 500 times for the first game, and 50 for the second</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The outcomes of the games do not depend on the number of flips.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) The probability of throwing heads is 0.5. By the law of large numbers, the more times you flip the coin, the more the relative frequency tends to become closer to this probability. With fewer tosses there is a greater chance of wide swings in the relative frequency.

content: During the 2015 season, Anthony Rizzo and Kris Bryant getting hits, one after the other, were independent events. The probability of both getting hits was 0.07645. The probability of Rizzo getting a hit and Bryant not getting a hit was 0.20155. What was the probability of Bryant getting a hit?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D)

P(Rizzo hits) = 0.20155 + 0.07645
By independence, P(Rizzo hits) P(Bryant hits) = P(both get hits)
(0.20155 + 0.07645)P(Bryant hits) = 0.07645

content: The average annual incomes of high school and college graduates working at a particular company are $21,000 and $35,000, respectively. If the company hires only personnel with at least a high school diploma and 20% of its employees have been through college, what is the mean income of the company employees?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) E(X) = μx = Î£xipi = 21,000(0.8) + 35,000(0.2) = 23,800

content: An insurance company charges $800 annually for car insurance. The policy specifies that the company will pay $1000 for a minor accident and $5000 for a major accident. If the probability of a motorist having a minor accident during the year is 0.2, and of having a major accident, 0.05, how much can the insurance company expect to make on a policy?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) 1000(0.2) + 5000(0.05) = 450, and 800 - 450 = 350.

content: You can choose one of three boxes. Box A has four $5 bills and a single $100 bill, box B has 400 $5 bills and 100 $100 bills, and box C has 24 $1 bills. You can have all of box C or blindly pick one bill out of either box A or box B. Which offers the greatest expected winning?

answers.D: <label>D. Either A or B, but not C</label>
answers.E: <label>E. All offer the same expected winning.</label>

explanation:

Explanation:

(E)

content: Given that 52% of the U.S. population are female and 15% are older than age 65, can we conclude that (0.52)(0.15) = 7.8% are women older than age 65?

answers.C: <label>C. Yes, by the law of large numbers.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. No, because the events are not independent.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. No, because the events are not mutually exclusive.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) P(E âˆ© F) = P(E)P(F) only if the events are independent. In this case, women live longer than men and so the events are not independent.

content: Mathematically speaking, casinos and life insurance companies make a profit because of

answers.A: <label>A. their understanding of sampling error and sources of bias.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. their use of well-designed, well-conducted surveys and experiments.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. their use of simulation of probability distributions.</label>

explanation:

Explanation:

(E) While the outcome of any single play on a roulette wheel or the age at death of any particular person is uncertain, the law of large numbers gives that the relative frequencies of specific outcomes in the long run tend to become closer to numbers called probabilities.
