content: Suppose the probability that you will receive an A in AP Statistics is 0.35, the probability that you will receive A's in both AP Statistics and AP Biology is 0.19, and the probability that you will receive an A in AP Statistics but not in AP Biology is 0.17. Which of the following is a proper conclusion?

answers.A: <label>A. The probability that you will receive an A in AP Biology is 0.36.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The probability that you didn't take AP Biology is .01.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The probability that you will receive an A in AP Biology but not in AP Statistics is 0.18.</label>

explanation:

(D) The probability that you will receive an A in AP Statistics but not in AP Biology must be 0.35 - 0.19 = 0.16, not 0.17.

content: You have a choice of three investments, the first of which gives you a 10% chance of making $1 million, otherwise you lose $25,000; the second of which gives you a 50% chance of making $500,000, otherwise you lose $345,000; and the third of which gives you an 80% chance of making $50,000, otherwise you make only $1,000. Assuming you will go bankrupt if you don't show a profit, which option should you choose for the best chance of avoiding bankruptcy?

answers.D: <label>D. Either the first or the second choice</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

(C) Even though the first two choices have a higher expected value than the third choice, the third choice gives a 100% chance of avoiding bankruptcy.

content: Suppose you toss a fair coin ten times and it comes up heads every time. Which of the following is a true statement?

answers.A: <label>A. By the law of large numbers, the next toss is more likely to be tails than another heads.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. By the properties of conditional probability, the next toss is more likely to be heads given that ten tosses in a row have been heads.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Coins actually do have memories, and thus what comes up on the next toss is influenced by the past tosses.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The law of large numbers tells how many tosses will be necessary before the percentages of heads and tails are again in balance.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The probability that the next toss will again be heads is 0.5.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) Coins have no memory, and so the probability that the next toss will be heads is .5 and the probability that it will be tails is 0.5. The law of large numbers says that as the number of tosses becomes larger, the percentage of heads tends to become closer to 0.5.

content: A city water supply system involves three pumps, the failure of any one of which crashes the system. The probabilities of failure for each pump in a given year are 0.025, 0.034, and 0.02, respectively. Assuming the pumps operate independently of each other, what is the probability that the system does crash during the year?
explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) The probabilities of each pump not failing are 1 - 0.025, 1 - 0.034, and 1 - 0.02, respectively. The probability of none failing is the product of (1 - 0.025)(1 - 0.034)(1 - 0.02). So the probability of at least one failing is 1 - (1 - 0.025)(1 - 0.034)(1 - 0.02).

content: Which of the following are true statements?

(B) If p > 0.5, the more likely numbers of successes are to the right and the lower numbers of successes have small probabilities, and so the histogram is skewed to the left. No matter what p is, if n is sufficiently large, the histogram will look almost symmetric.

content: Suppose that 60% of students who take the AP Statistics exam score 4 or 5, 25% score 3, and the rest score 1 or 2. Suppose further that 95% of those scoring 4 or 5 receive college credit, 50% of those scoring 3 receive such credit, and 4% of those scoring 1 or 2 receive credit. If a student who is chosen at random from among those taking the exam receives college credit, what is the probability that she received a 3 on the exam?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

(B)

content: Given the probabilities P(A) = 0.4 and P(A ∪ B) = 0.6, what is the probability P(B) if A and B are mutually exclusive? If A and B are independent?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) If A and B are mutually exclusive, P(A ∩ B) = 0. Thus 0.6 = 0.4 + P(B) - 0, and so P(B) = 0.2. If A and B are independent, then P(A ∩ B) = P(A)P(B). Thus 0.6 = 0.4 + P(B) - 0.4P(B), and so .

content: There are 20 students in an AP Statistics class. Suppose all are unprepared and randomly guess on each of ten multiple-choice questions, each with a choice of five possible answers. Which of the following is one run of a simulation to estimate the probability at least one student guesses correctly on over half the questions?

answers.A: <label>A. Assume "1" is the correct answer and "2, 3, 4, 5" are incorrect answers. Randomly pick 200 numbers between 1 and 5. Arrange the numbers into 20 groups of 10 each, each group corresponding to one of the students. For each student, count how many correct ("1") answers there are. Record whether at least one student has six or more correct answers.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Assume "2" is the correct answer and "1, 3, 4, 5" are incorrect answers. Assign the numbers 1-20 to the students. Randomly choose 200 numbers between 1 and 20. For each number chosen, randomly pick a number between 1 and 5. Record how many correct ("2") answers there are, divide by 20, and record whether this quotient is at least six.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Assume "3" is the correct answer and "1, 2, 4, 5" are incorrect answers. Assign the numbers 1-10 to the questions. Randomly choose 200 numbers between 1 and 10. For each number chosen, randomly pick a number between 1 and 5. Record how many correct ("3") answers there are, divide by 20, and record whether this quotient is at least six.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Assume "4" is the correct answer and "1, 2, 3, 5" are incorrect answers. Randomly choose 200 numbers between 1 and 5. Record how many correct ("4") answers there are, divide by 20, and record whether this quotient is at least six.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Assume "5" is the correct answer and "1, 2, 3, 4" are incorrect answers. Randomly pick 20 numbers between 1 and 5. Do this 10 times, and for each group of 20 note how many correct ("5") answers there are. Record whether at least one group has over half correct answers.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) For each of the 20 students, we must generate an answer to each of the 10 questions, and record if any student has at least 6 out of 10 correct answers.

content: An auto dealer offers discounts averaging $2,450 with a standard deviation of $575. If 50 autos are sold during one month, what is the expected value and standard deviation for the total discounts given?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Expected values and variances add. Thus,

E(Total) = E(X1) + E(X2) +...+ E(X50)
= 2,450 + 2,450 +...+ 2,450 = 50(2,450) = 122,500

content: An auto dealer pays an average of $8,750 with a standard deviation of $1,200 for used car trade-ins, and sells new cars for an average of $28,500 with a standard deviation of $3,100. Assuming independence of trade-in and new car prices for a customer, what is the standard deviation of the revenue the dealer should expect to make if a customer trades in a used car and buys a new one?

content: Suppose a retailer knows that the mean number of broken eggs per carton is 0.3 with a standard deviation of 0.18. In a shipment of 100 cartons, what is the expected number of broken eggs and what is the standard deviation? Assume independence between cartons.
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Expected values and variances add. Thus,

E(broken) = E(X1) + E(X2) +...+ E(X100) = 0.3 + 0.3 +...+ 0.3 = 100(0.3) = 30

content: Science majors in college pay an average of $650 per year for books with a standard deviation of $130, whereas English majors pay an average of $465 per year for books with a standard deviation of $90. What is the mean difference and standard deviation between the amounts paid for books by science and English majors?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) For a set of differences, means subtract, but variances add. Thus,

E(Sci - Eng) = E(Sci) - E(Eng) = 650 - 465 = 185

content: Which of the following is a true statement?

answers.A: <label>A. The area under a normal curve is always equal to 1, no matter what the mean and standard deviation are.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. All bell-shaped curves are normal distributions for some choice of μ and σ.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The smaller the standard deviation of a normal curve, the lower and more spread out the graph.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Depending upon the value of the standard deviation, normal curves with different means may be centered around the same number.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Depending upon the value of the standard deviation, the mean and median of a particular normal distribution may be different.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) The area under any probability distribution is equal to 1. Many bell-shaped curves are not normal curves. The smaller the standard deviation of a normal curve, the higher and narrower the graph. The mean determines the value around which the curve is centered; different means give different centers. Because of symmetry, the mean and median are identical for normal distributions.

content: Which of the following is a true statement?

answers.A: <label>A. The area under the standard normal curve between 0 and 2 is twice the area between 0 and 1.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The area under the standard normal curve between 0 and 2 is half the area between -2 and 2.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. For the standard normal curve, the interquartile range is approximately 3.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. For the standard normal curve, the range is 6.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. For the standard normal curve, the area to the left of 0.1 is the same as the area to the right of 0.9.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Statement (B) is true by symmetry of the normal curve, however 0.4772 is not twice 0.3413, 0.67 - (-0.67) is not 3, the range is not finite, and the P(z < 0.1) is more than 0.5 while P(z > 0.9) is less than 0.5.

content: Populations P1 and P2 are normally distributed and have identical means. However, the standard deviation of P1 is twice the standard deviation of P2. What can be said about the percentage of observations falling within two standard deviations of the mean for each population?

answers.A: <label>A. The percentage for P1 is twice the percentage for P2.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The percentage for P1 is greater, but not twice as great, as the percentage for P2.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The percentage for P2 is twice the percentage for P1.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The percentage for P2 is greater, but not twice as great, as the percentage for P1.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) All normal distributions have about 95% of their observations within two standard deviations of the mean.

Correct Answer: C

(C) Curve a has mean 6 and standard deviation 2, while curve b has mean 18 and standard deviation 1.

content: Assume the given distributions are normal. A trucking firm determines that its fleet of trucks averages a mean of 12.4 miles per gallon with a standard deviation of 1.2 miles per gallon on cross-country hauls. What is the probability that one of the trucks averages fewer than 10 miles per gallon?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) The z-score of 10 is . From Table A, to the left of -2 is an area of 0.0228. [normalcdf(0, 10, 12.4, 1.2) = 0.0228.]

content: Assume the given distributions are normal. A factory dumps an average of 2.43 tons of pollutants into a river every week. If the standard deviation is 0.88 tons, what is the probability that in a week more than 3 tons are dumped?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) The z-score of 3 is .

content: Assume the given distributions are normal. An electronic product takes an average of 3.4 hours to move through an assembly line. If the standard deviation is 0.5 hour, what is the probability that an item will take between 3 and 4 hours?
explanation:
Correct Answer: E

(E) The z-scores of 3 and 4 are and , respectively. From Table A, to the left of -0.8 is an area of 0.2119, and to the left of 1.2 is an area of 0.8849. Thus between 3 and 4 is an area of 0.8849 - 0.2119 = 0.6730. [normalcdf(3, 4, 3.4, .5) = 0.6731.]

content: Assume the given distributions are normal. The mean score on a college placement exam is 500 with a standard deviation of 100. Ninety-five percent of the test takers score above what?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) If 95% of the area is to the right of a score, 5% is to the left. Looking for 0.05 in the body of Table A, we note the z-score of -1.645. Converting this to a raw score gives 500 - 1.645(100) = 336. [invNorm(.05, 500, 100) = 336.]

content: Assume the given distributions are normal. The average noise level in a restaurant is 30 decibels with a standard deviation of 4 decibels. Ninety-nine percent of the time it is below what value?
explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) The critical z-score associated with 99% to the left is 2.326.

content: Assume the given distributions are normal. The mean income per household in a certain state is $9500 with a standard deviation of $1750. The middle 95% of incomes are between what two values?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) The critical z-scores associated with the middle 95% are ±1.96, and 9500 ± 1.96(1750) = 6070 and 12,930. [invNorm(.025, 9500, 1750) = 6070 and invNorm(.975, 9500, 1750) = 12,930.]

content: Assume the given distributions are normal. One company produces movie trailers with mean 150 seconds and standard deviation 40 seconds, while a second company produces trailers with mean 120 seconds and standard deviation 30 seconds. What is the probability that two randomly selected trailers, one produced by each company, will combine to less than three minutes?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

content: Assume the given distributions are normal. Jay Olshansky from the University of Chicago was quoted in Chance News as arguing that for the average life expectancy to reach 100, 18% of people would have to live to 120. What standard deviation is he assuming for this statement to make sense?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) The critical z-score associated with 18% to the right or 82% to the left is 0.92. Then 100 + 0.92σ = 120 gives σ = 21.7.

content: Assume the given distributions are normal. Cucumbers grown on a certain farm have weights with a standard deviation of 2 ounces. What is the mean weight if 85% of the cucumbers weigh less than 16 ounces?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) The critical z-score associated with 85% to the left is 1.04. Then μ + 1.04(2) = 16 gives μ = 13.92.

content: Assume the given distributions are normal. If 75% of all families spend more than $75 weekly for food, while 15% spend more than $150, what is the mean weekly expenditure and what is the standard deviation?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) The critical z-scores associated with 75% to the right (25% to the left) and with 15% to the right (85% to the left) are -0.67 and 1.04, respectively. Then {μ - 0.67σ = 75, μ + 1.04σ = 150} gives μ = 104.39 and σ = 43.86.

content: Assume the given distributions are normal. A coffee machine can be adjusted to deliver any fixed number of ounces of coffee. If the machine has a standard deviation in delivery equal to 0.4 ounce, what should be the mean setting so that an 8-ounce cup will overflow only 0.5% of the time?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) The critical z-score associated with 0.5% to the right (99.5% to the left) is 2.576. Then c + 2.576(0.4) = 8 gives c = 6.97.

content: Assume that a baseball team has an average pitcher, that is, one whose probability of winning any decision is 0.5. If this pitcher has 30 decisions in a season, what is the probability that he will win at least 20 games?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Using the normal as an approximation to the binomial, we have μ = 30(0.5) = 15, σ2 = 30(0.5)(0.5) = 7.5, σ = 2.739, , and 1 - 0.9495 = 0.0505. [Or binomcdf(30, .5, 10) = 0.0494.]

content: Given that 10% of the nails made using a certain manufacturing process have a length less than 2.48 inches, while 5% have a length greater than 2.54 inches, what are the mean and standard deviation of the lengths of the nails? Assume that the lengths have a normal distribution.

answers.E: <label>E. The mean and standard deviation cannot be computed from the information given.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) The critical z-scores for 10% to the left and 5% to the right are -1.282 and 1.645, respectively. Then {μ - 1.282σ = 2.48, μ + 1.645σ = 2.54} gives μ = 2.506 and σ = 0.0205.

content: Which of the following is a true statement?

answers.A: <label>A. The larger the sample, the larger the spread in the sampling distribution.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Bias has to do with the spread of a sampling distribution.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Provided that the population size is significantly greater than the sample size, the spread of the sampling distribution does not depend on the population size.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Sample parameters are used to make inferences about population statistics.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Statistics from smaller samples have less variability.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) The larger the sample, the smaller the spread in the sampling distribution. Bias has to do with the center, not the spread, of a sampling distribution. Sample statistics are used to make inferences about population proportions. Statistics from smaller samples have more variability.

content: Which of the following is an incorrect statement?
explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) It is always true that the sampling distribution of has mean μ and standard deviation . In addition, the sampling distribution will be normal if the population is normal and will be approximately normal if n is large even if the population is not normal. and Ïƒ are not equal unless n = 1.

content: Which of the following is a true statement?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) The sampling distribution of has a standard deviation which is smaller with larger n. While the sampling distribution of is never exactly normal, it is considered close to normal provided that both np and n(1 - p) are large enough (greater than 10 is a standard guide).

content: In a school of 2500 students, the students in an AP Statistics class are planning a random survey of 100 students to estimate the proportion who would rather drop lacrosse rather than band during this time of severe budget cuts. Their teacher suggests instead to survey 200 students in order to

answers.E: <label>E. make possible stratification between lacrosse and band.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Sample proportions are an unbiased estimator for the population proportion, and larger sample sizes lead to reduced variability.

content: The distribution of ages of people who died last year in the United States is skewed left. What happens to the sampling distribution of sample means as the sample size goes from n = 50 to n = 200?

answers.A: <label>A. The mean gets closer to the population mean, the standard deviation stays the same, and the shape becomes more skewed left.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The mean gets closer to the population mean, the standard deviation becomes smaller, and the shape becomes more skewed left.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The mean gets closer to the population mean, the standard deviation stays the same, and the shape becomes closer to normal.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The mean gets closer to the population mean, the standard deviation becomes smaller, and the shape becomes closer to normal.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The mean stays the same, the standard deviation becomes smaller, and the shape becomes closer to normal.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) The sampling distribution of has mean μ, standard deviation , and shape, which becomes closer to normal with larger n.

content: Which of the following is the best reason that the sample maximum is not used as an estimator for the population maximum?

answers.B: <label>B. The sampling distribution of the sample maximum is not binomial.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The sampling distribution of the sample maximum is not normal.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The sampling distribution of the sample maximum has too large a standard deviation.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The sample mean plus three sample standard deviations gives a much superior estimate for the population maximum.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) The maximum of a sample is never larger than the maximum of the population, so the mean of the sample maximums will not be equal to the population maximum. (A sampling distribution is unbiased if its mean is equal to the population parameter.)

content: Which of the following are unbiased estimators for the corresponding population parameters?
explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) All are unbiased estimators for the corresponding population parameters; that is, the means of their sampling distributions are equal to the population parameters.

content: Thirty-four percent of Americans say that math is the most important subject in school. In a random sample of 400 Americans, what is the probability that between 30% and 35% will say that math is the most important subject?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) The sample is given to be random, both np = (400)(0.34) = 136 ≥ 10 and n(1 - p) = (400)(0.66) = 264 ≥ 10, and our sample is clearly less than 10% of all people. So the sampling distribution of is approximately normal with mean 0.34 and standard deviation . With z-scores of and , the probability that the sample proportion is between 0.30 and 0.35 is normalcdf(-1.688,.422)= 0.618. [Or normalcdf(.3,.35,.34,.0237)= 0.618.]

content: Researchers found that in the aftermath of the 2011 Fukushima nuclear disaster, 12% of the pale grass blue butterfly larvae developed mutations as adults. What is the probability that in a random sample of 300 of these butterfly larvae, more than 15% developed mutations as adults?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) The sample is given to be random, both np = (300)(0.12) = 36 ≥ 10 and n(1 - p) = (300)(0.88) = 264 ≥ 10, and our sample is clearly less than 10% of all butterfly larvae. So the sampling distribution of is approximately normal with mean = 0.12 and standard deviation . With a z-score of , the probability that the sample proportion is more than 15% is P

content: Suppose using accelerometers in helmets, researchers determine that boys playing high school football absorb an average of 355 hits to the head with a standard deviation of 80 hits during a season (including both practices and games). What is the probability on a randomly selected team of 48 players that the average number of head hits per player is between 340 and 360?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) We have a random sample that is less than 10% of the high school football population. With a sample size of 48, the central limit theorem applies, and the sampling distribution of is approximately normal with mean = 355 and standard deviation . The z-scores of 340 and 360 are and , the probability of a sample mean between 340 and 360 is normalcdf(-1.299,.433)= 0.571. [Or normalcdf(340,360,355,11.547)= 0.571.]

content: It is estimated that school CO2 levels average 1200 ppm with a standard deviation of 300 ppm. In a random sample of 30 schools, what is the probability that the mean CO2 level is more than 1000, a level at which some researchers feel will cause a drop in academic performance?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) We have a random sample that is less than 10% of all schools. With a sample size of 30, the central limit theorem applies, and the sampling distribution of is approximately normal with mean = 1200 and standard deviation . The z-score of 1000 is , and the probability of a sample mean over 1000 is P

content: Binge drinking is a serious problem, killing more than 1700 college students per year. Suppose the incidence of binge drinking is 43% and 37%, respectively, at two large universities. In a random sample of 75 students at the first school and 80 students at the second, what is the probability that the difference (first minus second) between the percentages of binge drinkers is between 5% and 10%?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) We have two independent random samples, each less than 10% of their respective populations, and we note that n1p1 = 75(0.43) = 32.25, n1(1 - p1) = 75(0.57) = 42.75, n2p2 = 80(0.37) = 29.6, and n2(1 - p2) = 80(0.63) = 50.4 are all â‰¥10. Thus the sampling distribution of 1 - 2 is roughly normal with mean and standard deviation . The z-score of 0.05 is , the z-score of 0.10 is , and normalcdf(-.127,.509)= 0.245. [Or normalcdf(.05,.10,.06,.0786)= 0.245.]

content: Suppose "sleep-trained" babies (allowed to cry themselves to sleep) wake up an average of 1.2 times a night with a standard deviation of 0.3 times, while nontrained babies wake up an average of 1.8 times a night with a standard deviation of 0.5 times. In a random sample of 80 babies, half of which are sleep-trained, what is the probability that the nontrained babies in the sample wake up an average number of times greater than 0.75 more than the average of the sleep-trained babies?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) We have independent random samples, each less than 10% of babies, and both sample sizes are 40 â‰¥ 30, so the sampling distribution of 1 - 2 is roughly normal with mean and standard deviation . The z-score of 0.75 is , and normalcdf(1.627,1000)= 0.0519.

[Or normalcdf(.75,1000,.6,.0922)= 0.0519.]

content: Which of the following statements are true?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) The t-distributions are symmetric and mound-shaped, and they have more, not less, spread than the normal distribution.

content: Which of the following statements about t-distributions are true?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) The larger the number of degrees of freedom, the closer the curve to the normal curve. While around the 30 level is often considered a reasonable approximation to the normal curve, it is not the normal curve.

content: A study is to be performed to estimate the proportion of voters who believe the economy is "heading in the right direction." Which of the following pairs of sample size and population proportion p will result in the smallest variance for the sampling distribution of ?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) The variance for the sampling distribution of equals . A larger n in the denominator results in a smaller quotient, and (0.1)(0.9) < (0.5)(0.5).

content: A random sample of 50 high school girls has a mean of 287 Facebook friends with a standard deviation of 68 friends. What is the standard error of the difference (girls - boys) between the sample means?

content: In a recent study of fatal automobile crashes (http://www-nrd.nhtsa.dot.gov/Pubs/811870.pdf) for drivers ages 21-24, 32% were legally drunk, while for drivers ages 25-34, 29% were legally drunk. A simulation is conducted in which a random sample of 400 drivers ages 21-24 and a random sample of 400 drivers 25-34, all involved in fatal automobile crashes, are selected. The difference in proportions of those who were legally drunk is calculated, and this simulation is repeated 1000 times. Which of the following is most likely to occur in the simulated sampling distribution of the difference between the two sample proportions?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) The sampling distribution is roughly normal with a mean of μ = 0.32 - 0.29 = 0.03 and a standard deviation of

content: Changing from a 95% confidence interval estimate for a population proportion to a 99% confidence interval estimate, with all other things being equal,

answers.E: <label>E. This question cannot be answered without knowing the sample size.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

content: In general, how does doubling the sample size change the confidence interval size?

answers.E: <label>E. This question cannot be answered without knowing the sample size.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Increasing the sample size by a multiple of d divides the interval estimate by .

content: A confidence interval estimate is determined from the GPAs of a simple random sample of n students. All other things being equal, which of the following will result in a smaller margin of error?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) The margin of error varies directly with the critical z-value and directly with the standard deviation of the sample, but inversely with the square root of the sample size. The value of the sample mean and the population size do not affect the margin of error.

content: A survey was conducted to determine the percentage of high school students who planned to go to college. The results were stated as 82% with a margin of error of ±5%. What is meant by ±5%?

answers.A: <label>A. Five percent of the population were not surveyed.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. In the sample, the percentage of students who plan to go to college was between 77% and 87%.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The percentage of the entire population of students who plan to go to college is between 77% and 87%.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. It is unlikely that the given sample proportion result would be obtained unless the true percentage was between 77% and 87%.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Between 77% and 87% of the population were surveyed.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Although the sample proportion is between 77% and 87% (more specifically, it is 82%), this is not the meaning of Â±5%. Although the percentage of the entire population is likely to be between 77% and 87%, this is not known for certain.

content: Most recent tests and calculations estimate at the 95% confidence level that the maternal ancestor to all living humans called mitochondrial Eve lived 273,000 ±177,000 years ago. What is meant by "95% confidence" in this context?

answers.C: <label>C. There is a .95 probability that mitochondrial Eve lived between 96,000 and 450,000 years ago.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. If 20 random samples of data are obtained by this method, and a 95% confidence interval is calculated from each, then the true age of mitochondrial Eve will be in 19 of these intervals.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. 95% of all random samples of data obtained by this method will yield intervals that capture the true age of mitochondrial Eve.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) The 95% refers to the method: 95% of all intervals obtained by this method will capture the true population parameter. Nothing is certain about any particular set of 20 intervals. For any particular interval, the probability that it captures the true parameter is 1 or 0 depending upon whether the parameter is or isn't in it.

content: One month the actual unemployment rate in France was 13.4%. If during that month you took an SRS of 100 Frenchmen and constructed a confidence interval estimate of the unemployment rate, which of the following would have been true?

As long as n is large, s is a reasonable estimate of σ; however, again this is not measured by the margin of error. (With t-scores, there is a correction for using s as an estimate of σ.)

content: Under what conditions would it be meaningful to construct a confidence interval estimate when the data consist of the entire population?

Explanation:

(E) In determining confidence intervals, one uses sample statistics to estimate population parameters. If the data are actually the whole population, making an estimate has no meaning.

content: Is there a relationship between mishandled-baggage rates (number of mishandled bags per 1000 passengers) and percentage of on-time arrivals? Regression analysis of ten airlines gives the following TI-Nspire output (baggage rate is independent variable):

content:
Smoking is a known risk factor for cardiovascular and cancer diseases. A recent study (Rusanen et al., Archives of Internal Medicine, October 25, 2010) surveyed 21,123 members of a California health care system looking at smoking levels and risk of dementia (as measured by the Cox hazard ratio). Results are summarized in the following graph of 95% confidence intervals.

Which of the following is an appropriate conclusion?

answers.A: <label>A. Dementia somehow causes an urge to smoke.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Heavier smoking leads to a greater risk of dementia.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Cutting down on smoking will lower one's risk of dementia.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Heavier smoking is associated with more precise confidence intervals of dementia as measured by the hazard ratio.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. There is a positive association between smoking and risk of dementia.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) While there is clearly a positive association between smoking levels and hazard ratios, this was an observational study, not an experiment, so cause and effect (as implied in (A), (B), and (C)) is not an appropriate conclusion. The margins of error of the confidence intervals become greater (less precision) with heavier smoking.

content: Which of the following is a true statement?

answers.A: <label>A. A well-planned hypothesis test should result in a statement either that the null hypothesis is true or that it is false.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The alternative hypothesis is stated in terms of a sample statistic.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. If a sample is large enough, the necessity for it to be a simple random sample is diminished.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. When the null hypothesis is rejected, it is because it is not true.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Hypothesis tests are designed to measure the strength of evidence against the null hypothesis.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) We attempt to show that the null hypothesis is unacceptable by showing that it is improbable; however, we cannot show that it is definitely true or false. Both the null and alternative hypotheses are stated in terms of a population parameter, not a sample statistic. These hypotheses tests assume simple random samples.

content: Which of the following is a true statement?

answers.D: <label>D. If possible, always examine your data before deciding whether to use a one-sided or two-sided hypothesis test.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The alternative hypothesis is one-sided if there is interest in deviations from the null hypothesis in only one direction.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) The P-value of a test is the probability of obtaining a result as extreme (or more extreme) as the one obtained assuming the null hypothesis is true. Small P-values are evidence against the null hypothesis. The null and alternative hypotheses are decided upon before the data come in.

content:
Question below refers to the following:

Video arcades provide a vehicle for competition and status within teenage peer groups and are recognized as places where teens can hang out and meet their friends. The national PTA organization, concerned about the time and money being spent in video arcades by middle school students, commissions a statistical study to investigate whether or not middle school students are spending an average of over two hours per week in video arcades. Twenty communities are randomly chosen, five middle schools are randomly picked in each of the communities, and ten students are randomly interviewed at each school.

What is the parameter of interest?

answers.B: <label>B. A particular concern of the national PTA organization</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The mean amount of money spent in video arcades by middle school students</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The mean number of hours per week spent in video arcades by middle school students</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) The parameter of interest is μ = the mean number of hours per week which middle school students spend in video arcades.

content:
Question below refers to the following:

Video arcades provide a vehicle for competition and status within teenage peer groups and are recognized as places where teens can hang out and meet their friends. The national PTA organization, concerned about the time and money being spent in video arcades by middle school students, commissions a statistical study to investigate whether or not middle school students are spending an average of over two hours per week in video arcades. Twenty communities are randomly chosen, five middle schools are randomly picked in each of the communities, and ten students are randomly interviewed at each school.

What are the null and alternative hypotheses which the PTA is testing?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) The alternative hypothesis is always an inequality, either <, or >, or â‰ . In this case, the concern is whether middle school students are spending an average of more than two hours per week in video arcades.

content: A hypothesis test comparing two population proportions results in a P-value of 0.032. Which of the following is a proper conclusion?

answers.A: <label>A. The probability that the null hypothesis is true is 0.032.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The probability that the alternative hypothesis is true is 0.032.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The difference in sample proportions is 0.032.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The difference in population proportions is 0.032.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. None of the above are proper conclusions.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) The P-value is a conditional probability; in this case, there is a 0.032 probability of an observed difference in sample proportions as extreme (or more extreme) as the one obtained if the null hypothesis is assumed to be true.

content: A company manufactures a synthetic rubber (jumping) bungee cord with a braided covering of natural rubber and a minimum breaking strength of 450 kg. If the mean breaking strength of a sample drops below a specified level, the production process is halted and the machinery inspected. Which of the following would result from a Type I error?

answers.A: <label>A. Halting the production process when too many cords break.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Halting the production process when the breaking strength is below the specified level.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Halting the production process when the breaking strength is within specifications.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Allowing the production process to continue when the breaking strength is below specifications.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Allowing the production process to continue when the breaking strength is within specifications.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) This is a hypothesis test with H0: breaking strength is within specifications, and Ha: breaking strength is below specifications. A Type I error is committed when a true null hypothesis is mistakenly rejected.

content: One ESP test asks the subject to view the backs of cards and identify whether a circle, square, star, or cross is on the front of each card. If p is the proportion of correct answers, this may be viewed as a hypothesis test with H0: p = 0.25 and Ha: p > 0.25. The subject is recognized to have ESP when the null hypothesis is rejected. What would a Type II error result in?

answers.C: <label>C. Not recognizing that someone really has ESP</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Correctly realizing that someone doesn't have ESP</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Failing to understand the nature of ESP</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) A Type II error is a mistaken failure to reject a false null hypothesis or, in this case, a failure to realize that a person really does have ESP.

content: A coffee-dispensing machine is supposed to deliver 12 ounces of liquid into a large paper cup, but a consumer believes that the actual amount is less. As a test he plans to obtain a sample of 5 cups of the dispensed liquid and if the mean content is less than 11.5 ounces, to reject the 12-ounce claim. If the machine operates with a known standard deviation of 0.9 ounces, what is the probability that the consumer will mistakenly reject the 12-ounce claim even though the claim is true? (Assume that all conditions for inference are met.)
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

(B)

content: A pharmaceutical company claims that a medicine will produce a desired effect for a mean time of 58.4 minutes. A government researcher runs a hypothesis test of 40 patients and calculates a mean of = 59.5 with a standard deviation of s = 8.3. What is the P-value?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Medications having an effect shorter or longer than claimed should be of concern, so this is a two-sided test: Ha: μ â‰  58.4, and df = n - 1 = 40 - 1 = 39.

content: You plan to perform a hypothesis test with a level of significance of α = 0.05. What is the effect on the probability of committing a Type I error if the sample size is increased?

answers.A: <label>A. The probability of committing a Type I error decreases.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The probability of committing a Type I error is unchanged.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The probability of committing a Type I error increases.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The effect cannot be determined without knowing the relevant standard deviation.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The effect cannot be determined without knowing if a Type II error is committed.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) The level of significance is defined to be the probability of committing a Type I error, that is, of mistakenly rejecting a true null hypothesis.

content: A fast food chain advertises that their large bag of french fries has a weight of 150 grams. Some high school students, who enjoy french fries at every lunch, suspect that they are getting less than the advertised amount. With a scale borrowed from their physics teacher, they weigh a random sample of 15 bags. What is the conclusion if the sample mean is 145.8 g and standard deviation is 12.81 g? (Assume that all conditions for inference are met.)

answers.A: <label>A. There is sufficient evidence to prove the fast food chain advertisement is true.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. There is sufficient evidence to prove the fast food chain advertisement is false.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The students have sufficient evidence to reject the fast food chain's claim.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The students do not have sufficient evidence to reject the fast food chain's claim.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. There is not sufficient data to reach any conclusion.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

(D) , and with df = 14, P = 0.112. With this high P-value (0.112 > 0.10), the students do not have sufficient evidence to reject the fast food chain's claim. (T-Test gives P = 0.112423.)

content: A researcher believes a new diet should improve weight gain in laboratory mice. If ten control mice on the old diet gain an average of 4 ounces with a standard deviation of 0.3 ounces, while the average gain for ten mice on the new diet is 4.8 ounces with a standard deviation of 0.2 ounces, what is the P-value? content: A school superintendent must make a decision whether or not to cancel school because of a threatening snow storm. What would the results be of Type I and Type II errors for the null hypothesis: The weather will remain dry?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) A Type I error means that the null hypothesis is true (the weather remains dry), but you reject it (thus you needlessly cancel school). A Type II error means that the null hypothesis is wrong (the snow storm hits), but you fail to reject it (so school is not canceled).

content: A pharmaceutical company claims that 8% or fewer of the patients taking their new statin drug will have a heart attack in a 5-year period. content: What is the probability of mistakenly failing to reject a false null hypothesis when a hypothesis test is being conducted at the 5% significance level (α = 0.05)?

content: A research dermatologist believes that cancers of the head and neck will occur most often of the left side, the side next to a window when a person is driving. In a review of 565 cases of head/neck cancers, 305 occurred on the left side. What is the resulting P-value?

content: Suppose you do five independent tests of the form H0: µ = 38 versus Ha: µ > 38, each at the α = 0.01 significance level. What is the probability of committing a Type I error and incorrectly rejecting a true null hypothesis with at least one of the five tests?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) P(at least one Type I error) = 1 - P(no Type I errors) = 1 - (0.99)5 = 0.049

content: Given an experiment with H0: µ = 35, Ha: µ < 35, and a possible correct value of 32, you obtain a sample statistic of = 33. After doing analysis, you realize that the sample size n is actually larger than you first thought. Which of the following results from reworking with the increase in sample size?

answers.A: <label>A. Decrease in probability of a Type I error; decrease in probability of a Type II error; decrease in power.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Increase in probability of a Type I error; increase in probability of a Type II error; decrease in power.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Decrease in probability of a Type I error; decrease in probability of a Type II error; increase in power.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Increase in probability of a Type I error; decrease in probability of a Type II error; decrease in power.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Decrease in probability of a Type I error; increase in probability of a Type II error; increase in power.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) A larger sample size n reduces the standard deviation of the sampling distributions resulting in narrower sampling distributions so that for the given sample statistic, the P-value is smaller, and the probabilities of mistakenly rejecting a true null hypothesis or mistakenly failing to reject a false null hypothesis are both decreased. Furthermore, a lower Type II error results in higher power.

content: Thirty students volunteer to test which of two strategies for taking multiple-choice exams leads to higher average results. Each student flips a coin, and if heads, uses Strategy A on the first exam and then Strategy B on the second, while if tails, uses Strategy B first and then Strategy A. The average of all 30 Strategy A results is then compared to the average of all 30 Strategy B results. What is the conclusion at the 5% significance level if a two-sample hypothesis test, H0: µ1 = µ2, Ha: µ1 ≠ µ2,results in a P-value of 0.18?

answers.A: <label>A. The observed difference in average scores is significant.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The observed difference in average scores is not significant.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. A conclusion is not possible without knowing the average scores resulting from using each strategy.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. A conclusion is not possible without knowing the average scores and the standard deviations resulting from using each strategy.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. A two-sample hypothesis test should not be used here.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) The two-sample hypothesis test is not the proper one and can only be used when the two sets are independent. In this case, there is a clear relationship between the data, in pairs, one pair for each student, and this relationship is completely lost in the procedure for the two-sample test. The proper procedure is to run a one-sample test on the single variable consisting of the differences from the paired data.

content: Choosing a smaller level of significance, that is, a smaller α-risk, results in

answers.A: <label>A. a lower risk of Type II error and lower power.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. a lower risk of Type II error and higher power.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. a higher risk of Type II error and lower power.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. a higher risk of Type II error and higher power.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. no change in risk of Type II error or in power.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) With a smaller α, that is, with a tougher standard to reject H0, there is a greater chance of failing to reject a false null hypothesis, that is, there is a greater chance of committing a Type II error. Power is the probability that a Type II error is not committed, so a higher Type II error results in lower power.

content: The greater the difference between the null hypothesis claim and the true value of the population parameter,

answers.A: <label>A. the smaller the risk of a Type II error and the smaller the power.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. the smaller the risk of a Type II error and the greater the power.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. the greater the risk of a Type II error and the smaller the power.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. the greater the risk of a Type II error and the greater the power.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. the greater the probability of no change in Type II error or in power.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) If the null hypothesis is far off from the true parameter value, there is a greater chance of rejecting the false null hypothesis and thus a smaller risk of a Type II error. Power is the probability that a Type II error is not committed, so a lower Type II error results in higher power.

content:
A company selling home appliances claims that the accompanying instruction guides are written at a 6th grade reading level. An English teacher believes that the true figure is higher and with the help of an AP Statistics student runs a hypothesis test. The student randomly picks one page from each of 25 of the company's instruction guides, and the teacher subjects the pages to a standard readability test. The reading levels of the 25 pages are given in the following table:

Assuming that the conditions for inference are met, is there statistical evidence to support the English teacher's belief?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) With = 6.48 and s = 1.388, . Given df = 29, P = 0.048.
[A calculator gives P = 0.048322.]

content: Suppose H0: p = 0.4, and the power of the test for the alternative hypothesis p = 0.35 is 0.75. Which of the following is a valid conclusion?

answers.A: <label>A. The probability of committing a Type I error is 0.05.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The probability of committing a Type II error is 0.65.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. If the null hypothesis is true, the probability of rejecting it is 0.25.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. If the null hypothesis is false, the probability of failing to reject it is 0.65.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) If the alternative is true, the probability of failing to reject H0 and thus committing a Type II error is 1 minus the power, that is, 1 - 0.75 = 0.25.

content: A factory is located close to a city high school. The manager claims that the plant's smokestacks spew forth an average of no more than 350 pounds of pollution per day. As an AP Statistics project, the class plans a one-sided hypothesis test with a critical value of 375 pounds. Suppose the standard deviation in daily pollution poundage is known to be 150 pounds and the true mean is 385 pounds. If the sample size is 100 days, what is the probability that the class will mistakenly fail to reject the factory manager's false claim?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B)
[normalcdf(-100, -10/15) = 0.252492.]

content: For which of the following is a matched pairs t-test not appropriate?

answers.A: <label>A. Heights of both spouses of 50 randomly selected married couples.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Heights of both people in pairs formed by 50 randomly selected people.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Heights of twins for 50 randomly selected pairs of twins.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Heights of 50 randomly selected children at age 5 and then at age 6.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Heights of 50 randomly selected children from Canada and the United States in pairs by matching family income.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Two-sample t-tests of the difference between two population means are appropriate only when the two samples being compared are independent of each other. In all the answers except for (B), the data are selected in natural related pairs and the proper procedure is a one-sample analysis on the set of differences.

content:
Do high school girls apply to more colleges than high school boys? A two-sample t-test of the hypotheses H0: µgirls = µboys versus Ha: µgirls > µboys results in a P-value of 0.02.

Which of the following statements must be true?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B)

With 0.02 in the tail, a confidence over 0.48 + 0.48 = 0.96 will contain 0.

content: A random sample of mice is obtained, and each mouse is timed as it moves through a maze to a reward treat at the end. After several days of training, each mouse is timed again. The data should be analyzed using
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) There are two observations of each mouse, a before time and an after time. These two times are dependent so a paired t-test is appropriate, not a two-sample test.

content:
To test the claim that dogs bite more or less depending upon the phase of the moon, a university hospital counts admissions for dog bites and classifies with moon phase.

Which of the following is the proper conclusion?

answers.A: <label>A. The data prove that dog bites occur equally during all moon phases.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The data prove that dog bites do not occur equally during all moon phases.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The data give evidence that dog bites occur equally during all moon phases.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The data give evidence that dog bites do not occur equally during all moon phases.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The data do not give sufficient evidence to conclude that dog bites are related to moon phases.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) The expected counts if dog bites occur equally during all moon phases are each (32 + 27 + 47 + 38) = 36. A chi-square goodness-of-fit test gives , and with df = 4 - 1 = 3, P(Ï‡2 > 6.167) = 0.1038. With this large a P-value (0.1038 > 0.10), there is not sufficient evidence to conclude that dog bites are related to moon phases.

content: For a project, a student randomly picks 100 fellow AP Statistics students to survey on whether each has either a PC or Apple at home (all students in the school have a home computer) and what score (1, 2, 3, 4, 5) each expects to receive on the AP exam. A chi-square test of independence results in a test statistic of 8. How many degrees of freedom are there?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) df = (rows - 1)(columns - 1) = (2 - 1)(5 - 1) = 4

content: A random sample of 100 former student-athletes are picked from each of the 16 colleges that are members of the Big East conference. Students are surveyed about whether or not they feel they received a quality education while participating in varsity athletics. A 2 × 16 table of counts is generated. Which of the following is the most appropriate test to determine whether there is a difference among these schools as to the student-athlete perception of having received a quality education.

answers.A: <label>A. A chi-square goodness-of-fit test for a uniform distribution</label>
answers.C: <label>C. A chi-square test of homogeneity of proportions</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Picking separate samples from each of 16 populations and classifying according to one variable (perception of quality education) is a survey design which is most appropriately analyzed using a chi-square test of homogeneity of proportions.

content: According to theory, blood types in the general population occur in the following proportions: 46% O, 40% A, 10% B, and 4% AB. Anthropologists come upon a previously unknown civilization living on a remote island. A random sampling of blood types yields the following counts: 77 O, 85 A, 23 B, and 15 AB. Is there sufficient evidence to conclude that the distribution of blood types found among the island population differs from that which occurs in the general population?

answers.A: <label>A. The data prove that blood type distribution on the island is different from that of the general population.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The data prove that blood type distribution on the island is not different from that of the general population.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The data give sufficient evidence at the 1% significance level that blood type distribution on the island is different from that of the general population.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The data give sufficient evidence at the 5% significance level, but not at the 1% significance level, that blood type distribution on the island is different from that of the general population.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The data do not give sufficient evidence at the 5% significance level that blood type distribution on the island is different from that of the general population.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) With 77 + 85 + 23 + 15 = 200 samples, the expected counts if the blood type distribution on the island is the same as that of the general population are 46% of 200 = 92, 40% of 200 = 80, 10% of 200 = 20, and 4% of 200 = 8. A chi-square goodness-of-fit test gives , and with df = 4 - 1 = 3, P(Ï‡2 > 9.333) = 0.0252. With a P-value this small (0.0252 < 0.05), there is sufficient evidence at the 5% significance level that blood type distribution on the island is different from that of the general population.

content: Is there a relationship between education level and sports interest? A study cross-classified 1500 randomly selected adults in three categories of education level (not a high school graduate, high school graduate, and college graduate) and five categories of major sports interest (baseball, basketball, football, hockey, and tennis). The χ2-value is 13.95. Is there evidence of a relationship between education level and sports interest?

answers.A: <label>A. The data prove there is a relationship between education level and sports interest.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The evidence points to a cause-and-effect relationship between education and sports interest.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. There is sufficient evidence at the 5% significance level of a relationship between education level and sports interest.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. There is sufficient evidence at the 10% significance level, but not at the 5% significance level, of a relationship between education level and sports interest.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) With df = (3 - 1)(5 - 1) = 8, P(χ2 > 13.95) = 0.083. Since 0.05 < 0.083 < 0.10, there is sufficient evidence at the 10% significance level, but not at the 5% significance level, of a relationship between education level and sports interest.

content: A disc jockey wants to determine whether middle school students and high school students have similar music tastes. Independent random samples are taken from each group, and each person is asked whether he/she prefers hip-hop, pop, or alternative. A chi-square test of homogeneity of proportions is performed, and the resulting P-value is below 0.05. Which of the following is a proper conclusion?

answers.A: <label>A. There is sufficient evidence that for all three music choices the proportion of middle school students who prefer each choice is equal to the corresponding proportion of high school students.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. There is sufficient evidence that the proportion of middle school students who prefer hip-hop is different from the proportion of high school students who prefer hip-hop.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. There is sufficient evidence that for all three music choices the proportion of middle school students who prefer each choice is different from the corresponding proportion of high school students.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. There is sufficient evidence that for at least one of the three music choices the proportion of middle school students who prefer that choice is equal to the corresponding proportion of high school students.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. There is sufficient evidence that for at least one of the three music choices the proportion of middle school students who prefer that choice is different from the corresponding proportion of high school students.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) With a P-value this small (less than 0.05), there is sufficient evidence in support of the alternative hypothesis Ha: the distributions of music preferences are different, that is, they differ for at least one of the proportions.

content: A geneticist claims that four species of fruit flies should appear in the ratio 1:3:3:9. Suppose that a sample of 2000 flies contained 110, 345, 360, and 1185 flies of each species, respectively. Is there sufficient evidence to reject the geneticist's claim?

answers.A: <label>A. The data prove the geneticist's claim.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The data prove the geneticist's claim is false.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The data do not give sufficient evidence to reject the geneticist's claim.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The data give sufficient evidence to reject the geneticist's claim.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The evidence from this data is inconclusive.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) With 1 + 3 + 3 + 9 = 16, according to the geneticist the expected number of fruit flies of each species is , , , . A chi-square goodness-of-fit test gives

,

and with df = 4 - 1 = 3, P(Ï‡2 > 8) = 0.0460. With a P-value this small (0.0460 < 0.05), there is sufficient evidence at the 5% significance level to reject the geneticist's claim.

content:
A food biologist surveys people at an ice cream parlor, noting their taste preferences and cross-classifying against the presence or absence of a particular marker in a saliva swab test.

Is there sufficient evidence of a relationship between taste preference and the marker presence?

answers.A: <label>A. At the 10% significance level, the data prove that there is a relationship between taste preference and the presence of the marker.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. At the 10% significance level, the data prove that there is no relationship between taste preference and the presence of the marker.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. There is sufficient evidence at the 5% significance level of a relationship between taste preference and the presence of the marker.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. There is sufficient evidence at the 10% significance level, but not at the 5% significance level, of a relationship between taste preference and the presence of the marker.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. There is not sufficient evidence at the 10% significance level of a relationship between taste preference and the presence of the marker.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) A chi-square test of independence gives Ï‡2 = 2.852, and with df = 2, we find P = 0.2403, and since 0.2403 > 0.10, there is not sufficient evidence at the 10% significance level of a relationship between taste preference and the presence of the marker.

content:
Random samples of 25 students are chosen from each high school class level, students are asked whether or not they are satisfied with the school cafeteria food, and the results are summarized in the following table:

Is there sufficient evidence of a difference in cafeteria food satisfaction among the class levels?

answers.A: <label>A. The data prove that there is a difference in cafeteria food satisfaction among the class levels.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. There is sufficient evidence of a linear relationship between food satisfaction and class level.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. There is sufficient evidence at the 1% significance level of a difference in cafeteria food satisfaction among the class levels.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. There is sufficient evidence at the 5% significance level, but not at the 1% significance level, of a difference in cafeteria food satisfaction among the class levels.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) A chi-square test of homogeneity gives Ï‡2 = 5.998, and with df = 3, the P-value is 0.1117. With a P-value this large (0.1117 > 0.10) there is not sufficient evidence of a difference in cafeteria food satisfaction among the class levels.

content:
Can dress size be predicted from a woman's height? In a random sample of 20 female high school students, dress size versus height (cm) gives the following regression results:

Is there statistical evidence of a linear relationship between dress size and height?

answers.B: <label>B. No, because 0.128 is above any reasonable significance level.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Yes, because by any reasonable observation, taller women tend to have larger dress sizes.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Yes, because the computer printout does give a regression equation.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. There is sufficient evidence at the 10% significance level, but not at the 5% level.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) The relevant P-value is 0.065 which is less than 0.10 but greater than 0.05.

content:
To study the relationship between calories (kcal) and fat (g) in pizza, slices of 14 randomly selected major brand pizzas are chemically analyzed. Computer printout for regression:

What is measured by S = 1.27515?

answers.C: <label>C. Variability in the slope (g/kcal) of the regression line</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) In computer printouts of regression analysis, "S" typically gives the standard deviation of the residuals.

content: A 95% confidence interval for the slope of a regression line is calculated to be (-0.783, 0.457). Which of the following must be true?

answers.A: <label>A. The slope of the regression line is 0.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The slope of the regression line is -0.326.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. A scatterplot of the data would show a linear pattern.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. A residual plot would show no pattern.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) The slope of the regression line is -0.163, which is the middle of the confidence interval. The correlation coefficient has the same sign as the slope.

content:

Which of the following is an appropriate test statistic for testing the null hypothesis that the slope of the regression line is greater than 0? (Assume all conditions for inference are met.)
